news politics uk-faces-winter-discontent--"Boris Johnson says We must be clear that we cannot simply eliminate Covid as he announces delay to roadmapByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political EditorAletha Adu:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsBrits are set to face a dficult winter with rising energy bills, Covid spikes and the destruction of financial schemes helping those most in need. Around . million households on Universal Credit will see their energy bills rise signicantly in October while losing their £ a week uplt payments a week at the same time. Boris Johnson has tried to assure the nation that Christmas is still on, but food shortages are still on the cards. Read on for a breakdown of the issues you should look out for from next month. Rising energy prices Tories have admitted that Brits face a tough winter ahead - with people in the North more likely to be hammered by rising energy prices.A surge in global gas prices has put pressure on domestic energy suppliers, several of which have already gone bust.Spiralling wholesale costs look set to filter down to household bills.The energy price cap protects consumers from sudden hikes in their bills, but it also means that suppliers have gone to the wall as they can’t pass on higher costs to their customers.But some .million households have seen their providers collapse, meaning they face uncertainty about which company will take on their supply and how much it will cost.The energy price cap is already set to rise on October  by £, and ministers are in talks with regulator Ofgem about the next review in Aprilgas costs remain high.Petrol shortagesMotorists are facing fuel shortages at the pumps as a lack of HGV drivers wreaked havoc on the supply chain.BP, Esso and Tesco petrol forecourts were hit by shortages, with large queues reported on Friday as drivers tried to fill up.BP said that around  of its , petrol forecourts were closed due to a lack of available fuel, with between  and  sites affected by the loss of at least one grade of fuel.There is a shortage of , drivers, according to the Road Haulage Association, with the situation exacerbated by Covid pressures and Brexit red tape.Ministers were locked in talks on Friday over how to alleviate the shortage, with changes to immigration rules considered to make it easier for foreign drivers to fill the gap. Empty shelvesShoppers have already seen some empty shelves due to a shortage of carbon dioxide linked to the global gas shortage.US-owned fertiliser plant CF Industries was handed a Government bailout to restart its UK operations after halting production due to the gas price rise.Its UK plants are major suppliers of CO, which it produces as a by-product.Carbon dioxide is used for a range of things in the food sector, including stunning animals before slaughter and keeping fresh products chilled.The shortage of lorry drivers has also compounded issues.Retailers warned there were just  days to save Christmas from signicant disruption due to the lack of hauliers.The British Retail Consortiumsaid festive disruption would be inevitableprogress is not made swtly. Furlough comes to an end The furlough scheme will shut down next week on September . One million Brits are set to still be on furlough when it comes to an end, experts have revealed. The Resolution Foundation projected one million employees are set to remain on the scheme right up until the last moment. Of those, “the majority” willto their jobs but hundreds of thousands will need to find new work in October. Since it launched last March, furlough has supported .million jobs by paying up to % of people’s wages - at a cost of nearly £billion to the taxpayer.But there are fears of a cost of living crisis - as energy bills are rising on October  and Universal Credit payments are being slashed from October .Covid winter A leading health expert said Coronavirus could resemble the common cold by spring as peopleaposs immunity to the virus is boosted by vaccines and exposure. But we still have a fierce winter ahead of us. Professor Sir John Bell, regius professor of medicine at Oxford University, himself admitted winter needs to pass as double jabbed Brits are still at risk of the virus. In the coming weeks we could see Covid hospitalisations in England rising to more than , a day, according to Government scientic advisors. This would be higher than the third lockdown peak. Worryingly for the Government, which has said that instructing people to work from home is only a “possibility”cases soar, SPI-M said there was “clear consensus” that the measure had kept the pandemic under control in recent months. Boris Johnson outlined his plan for tackling Covid over the winter months, a period when respiratory viruses thrive.Plan aposAapos revolves around booster jabs for the over-s and vaccinating - to -year-olds. While plan aposBapos, measures enforced could include mandatory vaccine passports, face masks in public places and encouraging people to work from home. Universal Credit A million and a half working people face being plunged into “hardship” this winter as their benefits are slashed by £ a week, at the end of this month. Citizens Advice research showed % of working claimants fear they will struggle to pay bills, fall into debt or be forced to sell belongings to make up for the £,-a-year shortfall in their income. About one in four working recipients - equivalent to , people - worry they will be unable to afford food or other basic necessities like toiletries.Even Boris Johnson could not sayhe could survive on the usual Universal Credit payment earlier this week.The Prime Minister was askedhe could get by on just £ a week - the standard UC allowance for a couple over  after UC is slashed next month.The temporary “uplt” was announced in March last year as the coronavirus pandemic hit Britain.Calls to extend the rise are mounting amid growing warnings of a winter living standards crisis. title: boy 11 walk two miles
story: :root Boy walks  miles on busy roads to school after bus driver refuses £ noteKelly Mercer, , says son Ashton was left in tears after the driver of the Arriva bus in North Wales refused his £ Scottish note and he had to walk alone to school on a dangerous stretch of roadAshton, , was told his cash payment would not be accepted, his mum claimed Image: North Wales LiveByAaron LennoxTim Hanlon:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsAn -year-old boy was left crying at a bus stop and forced to walk two miles to school on a dangerous stretch of road because the driver wouldnapost accept his cash payment, claimed his mum.Kelly Mercer, , says son Ashton was refused a ride on the Arriva bus that would have taken him direct to the school gates of Ysgol Aberconwy and instead had to cross busy roads on his walk, reported NorthWalesLive.The schoolboy would normally pay the fare using the Arriva App, but earlier that morning was having issues with it meaning he had no option but to pay in cash. He attempted to pay for his fare on board using a £ Scottish sterling note and claims to have been told the note was not a legal tender. It left him with no option but to walk the two mile journey to school which involved crossing the Conwy bridge and busy roads from Llandudno Junction.Speaking to North Wales Live, Kelly said: “I noticed The Arriva app wasn’t working earlier that morning when I tried buying Ashtonaposs bus ticket for him to get to school. “I gave him a five pound note, to get afor the day in hope that the app would work the following day so he could get his ‘M-Ticket’. “Unfortunately it happened to be a Scottish sterling note - which, regardless is a legal tender. “Ashton was waiting with friends on Victoria Drive for the bus and when it came the driver refused the payment, and told him the payment wasn’t a valid form of payment and refused to accept the note and making him exit the bus before it left. “He was left alone at one of Llandudno Junctions’ busiest points at half eight in the rush hour morning whilst the bus drove off with his friends on. “Having only been at the school two weeks, and turning  only six months ago, Ashton was left to walk to school which is just over two- miles from the bus stop in the freezing cold crying his eyes out that early in the morning. “He recently had stitches in his eyebrow from a head injury, and the stitches are noticeable, yet that driver still refused him, anything could have happened on that route to school.” She says she has contacted Arriva about what happened, but claims sheaposs had no apology, only a comment confirming that no child should be left alone at the side of the street. She added: Iaposm thankful that Ashton was so nervous about starting the school as this allowed me to drive the route with him several times before the term started, little did I know that would come into play for such silly reasons. ”You hand over your child to them. You expect that your child will be able to get to school safely. As a grown man, making a child walk two miles to school, that driver should feel ashamed of himself.” Arriva has apologised for the incident after being contacted by MirrorOnline and said they will speak to the family. It said in a statement: We apologise for this incident, which has been fully investigated by our Depot team with the driver.It is our intention to reach out to the family directly on this matter. The safety of our customers, and our staff, whilst travelling with Arriva is our main priority. Arrivaaposs website states: Children aged under  and those people who, in the reasonable opinion of the driver, are vulnerable, at risk or in distress, and are unable to pay their fare will be carried at all times. They may be asked to provide their name and address in order that the fare due could be collected at a later date. In these circumstances, the driver will issue a single ticket for one journey allowing the inidual to travel to their home or the nearest stop thereto. title: builder says hes solved housing
story: :root Builder says hes solved the housing crisis with tiny two-bed home on wheelsChris Metcalf, from Falmouth, has built a two-bedroom transportable house that has all the same necessities as a regular property. It is made of metal and wood and is on sale for £,The house on wheels is up for sale for £, and is stylishly decorated throughout Image: DeeGee PHOTO   SWNSByShiler Mahmoudi:,  Sep | commentsA home builder believes his pint-sized property built on wheels and on sale for £K is the solution to the housing crisis. The unusual property is made of metal and wood and has everything a normal house would, but with one main dference - it is built on a trailer. The tiny Cornish house makes for a great holiday home as it can be attached to a car and driven around. The property, which is on sale in Falmouth, consists of a fully installed navy kitchen and stylish grey bathroom. It also has two bedrooms, making it perfect for a family, and a living room - as well as electricity and plumbing throughout. Chris Metcalf, the brains behind the property, believes homes such as this could be the key to ending the housing crisis. In Britain, a record amount of people are unable to buy a property, butmore homes such as this one were built, that could maybe change. The homeaposs advert reads: The Tiny House On Wheels is a locally made, unique and innovative housing solution.  Built on top of a purpose built steel chassis for ease of transporting to its forever home, the Tiny House is ideal for additional guest accommodation, a den for teenagers, or even a work from home study! Popular with buyers looking for an additional Air B  B type income, the Tiny House On Wheels can be parked on private landand mains Electrics and water hook up capability. The Tiny House has everything you need for comfortable day to day living, with a fully fitted kitchen and bathroom, a double bedroom and a single bedroom. The Tiny House is both stylish and finished to a high specication and is to be sold complete with fixtures and fittings. The property is being marketed by Martin  Co. and is on sale for £,. Mr Metcalf, an Electrician, spent more than a year building the home - which is advertised on Rightmove. He said: apos“ think it’s a really cool idea. There’s a shortage of properties in the South West at the moment. aposaposFamilies who might want extra accommodation, but don’t want to or can’t buy a bigger house or move home - this would be ideal.aposapos Comment MORE ON property newsDiyers" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts from our Property Market newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: bus shelter made giants baffles
story: :root Bus shelter made for giants baffles villagers with seats  inches off the groundA new bus shelter built in Fleering, Essex has been made too high, meaning villagers cannot reach the floor when they sit down. Commuters in the area have joked it has been made for giantsA local councillor is concerned that the bus shelter may mean that those with injuries will not be able to use it Image: James Linsell-Clark  SWNSByShiler Mahmoudi:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep A bus stop has left villagers baffled as its seats are  inches too high - meaning no one can touch the floor when sitting. Residents joke the bus stop in Fleering, Essex, which has been newly installed, was made for giants. Local Councillor Paul Thorogood has said that his legs dangle when he sits on the seat- and he is ft tall. The height of the seats isn’t very user-friendly...unless you’re a giant! he complained. Iaposm ft and my legs are hanging off the edge. For a ft ins tall pensioner with a dodgy knee or hip it’s totally unusable. The bus shelter seats are meant to be  inches high. But one is  inches and the other is  inches.  Theyaposre brand new and should be fitted at the correct height. Cllr Thorogood said the developer that paid for the new bus stops, Bloor Homes, did so as part of a deal whereby they would erect  new homes in the area. However, it is Essex County Council and not Bloor Homes that must pay for any upkeep, leaving the tax payer to foot the bill for the replacement.  It is hoped that the developer will fix the bus shelter. Cllr Thorogood said: Somethingaposs not quite right. They havenapost fixed it yet but it will be in the pipeline hopefully. “Many people who are elderly or have a disability need to be able to sit down when waiting for a bus. “At the moment, they can’t.” Bloor Homes and Essex County Council were contacted for comment. title: cardiff least safe city uk
story: :root UKs most dangerous city where locals feel least safe is revealed - see listThe Welsh capital of Cardf was closely followed by London and Birmingham - with four in ten Birmingham residents installing CCTV and alarms at home due to crime fearsThree in ten adults living in Cardf fear for their safety even in the daytime Image: Matthew Horwood Getty ImagesByAndrew Young:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep  Cardf is deemed one of the least safe cities in the UK due to an increase in kne crime, murders, vandalism and car theft, according to people living there.A poll of , adults, across  major UK cities, rated the safest places to live, with Cardf lowest in the list, followed by London and Birmingham. A staggering  percent of adults living in Cardf don’t feel safe at all on the streets at night, while another  percent worry about their safety even during the daytime. Nearly four in tenliving in Birmingham have installed CCTV and alarms at home to curb their fears about safety. Just under halfof people living in London would feel much safer with a police station in their neighbourhood - and just over a quarter in the capital would even consider legally owning a gun or kne for self-protection.  In comparison, Sheffield, Southampton, and Edinburgh came out as the top three safest cities to live in, with less than one in ten adults in the Scottish capital experiencing any sort of crime. Half of those in Southampton would recommend living in the city to friends, due to feeling so secure there. The stats emerged in a study to mark the launch of the new series of crime drama Murdertown on Crime+Investigation.  A spokesman said: Despite being popular living spots, it’s surprising to see some of the most common cities deemed unsafe - particularly the likes of Cardf, London and Birmingham. “There are clear concerns of activity from the British public that they could be a victim or witness a crime when walking around at night or even in during the daytime. “The new TV series will aim to uncover the most shocking murders in the UK and examine the impact they had on the cities around them.” Norwich and Leicester complete the top five safest cities, while Bristol and Leeds come further down the chart, ranking th and th. Researchers found Londoners are most likely to have experienced crime in the capital- an increase of  percent since . Most common wrongdoings include unprovoked acts of violence , fraudand muggings . And over a quarter of adultsin Cardf have witnessed a crime - up from  percent three years ago.  Almost a thirdadmitted they were a victim of crime themselves, compared to just  percent of adults living in the Welsh city in . Of these illegal acts, home break-ins were most common , followed by fraudand car theft- indicating crime activity has increased since  and during the pandemic. But research, commissioned via OnePoll, found overall  percent of adults would remain in the area they live in as they feel safe when in their own home. And to make their property safer to live in,  percent have installed smart lights that turn on when they’re outdoors, and  percent have added in extra locks around the house. Other measures added to make their home secure include security cameras, growing big hedges around the property and buying a guard dog. Outside of the home, one in five respondents feels safe most of the time - but six in ten won’t go out after dark unless they have to.  And one fth would feel safer in their citythey didn’t know of so many attacks or break-ins nearby, while  percent can’t help but pay attention to local gossip. For a resounding four in ten adults, a bigger police presence would make them feel more protected, while a third want more CCTV and one quarter want a local police station. When it comes to law enforcement, more than half of British adults do not feel the police are able to keep their area safe. And  percent feel women in particular are being let down by the police following the Sarah Everard case. The spokesman for Murdertown added: “The UK police force play a vital role in keeping our cities safe and ensure people feel comfortable to go about their normal lives without causing any issues. “Of course, that’s easier said than done when staffing levels can be an issue, and some cities have such high crime rates to contend with.”There will be more stories unveiled in Murdertown’s new ten-part series which premieres on Crime+Investigation on th September at pm.TOP  SAFEST CITIES TO LIVE IN THE UK...Edinburgh Southampton Sheffield Norwich Leicester Manchester Newcastle Cambridge Liverpool Glasgow Bristol Leeds Birmingham London CardfMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON CCTVCrimeCity of CardfSouth Wales PoliceCity of Edinburgh" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: costa coffee customers stunned over
story: :root Costa Coffee customers stunned over rude advert as chain forced to apologiseRichard Hards, , initially thought the crude Facebook post directed to freshers was fake but was shocked when the link went to the Costa Coffee offers pageA Costa Coffee Facebook post urging students to fuel morning lectures or wild nights out Image: Kennedy News and MediaByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Sep | commentsCosta Coffee has been forced to apologise for stunning customers with a rude advert urging students to flick the bean to fuel wild nights out.Richard Hards, , initially thought the crude Facebook post was fake but was stunned when he clicked on the link and was taken to the Costa Coffee offers page.In a Costa Coffee Facebook post by the Dunmail Park branch in Workington, Cumbria, flick the bean refers to flicking a coffee bean into a cup to win prizes. However, the same phrase also has connotations to mean female masturbation. Richard, from South West London, said: A friend of mine sent me the post saying aposwhat on earth is Costa thinking apos  At first I thought it was a hoax, there was a bit of me that thought aposthat canapost be real, someoneaposs made thatapos. I did my due diligence, rather than just sharing it, and found the post on Facebook. When I saw the phrasing aposflick the beanapos I thought apossomeone needs to check the definition on Urban Dictionaryapos. I donapost know whether [the person responsible] was being a bit cheeky.  Thereaposs a bit of me that hopes it is very tongue in cheek but I think whoever signed it off might not have necessarily got the underlying joke in there. Itaposs a bit risque. Itaposs something I would imagine a smaller company that was trying to get peopleaposs attention would run with for a little giggle, but slightly surprised to see it from a national brand like Costa.  The ad put a very cheeky smile on my face for the rest of the day. The Dunmail Park Facebook post read: FRESHERS! Fuel your early morning lectures OR the start of your wild nights out with a discounted or even a FREE Costa treat! Get lucky when you flick the coffee bean into one of the Costa cups to reveal a surprise deal. Play aposFLICK THE BEANapos here! The chef and owner of Boxed Local shared the now-deleted Facebook post from the Dunmail Park branch onto his own Instagram page yesterday morning [nd September].Richard wrote: @costacoffee know how to start the day right! £flickthebean. Four hours later Costa Coffeeaposs Instagram account replied, quipping: Canapost take credit for this one! - Natalie. The Facebook post was swtly deleted while similar posts on other branchesapos Facebook pages with the same promotion were later deleted. The offers section of Costa Coffeeaposs website is still live for people to play the game and potentially scoop a prize. Richard said: I imagine they may have got a bit of flack - a family-friendly company posting things like that. Itaposs a little bit on the nose, but Iaposm a little bit sad to see it come down. A Costa Coffee spokesman said: This competition was run by one of our franchise partners in a small number of stores and was not approved by Costa Coffee. We apologise for any offence caused and have requested the immediate removal of the competition. title: couple 24 year age gap
story: :root Couple with -year age gap slam cruel strangers who branded husband a paedoBill and Lauren Kenn, from Kirkcaldy, Fe, Scotland, said strangers gawp at them when they hold hands in the street and Bill has been accused of liking children due to their relationshipLauren and Bill Kenn have refused to let the cruel comments bother them Image: HotSpot MediaByCandice FernandezMatthew DreschReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA woman whose husband is  years her senior has revealed how strangers cruelly labelled him a paedo. Lauren, , and Bill Kenn, , from Kirkcaldy, Fe, in Scotland, have been together for eight years, but still endure cruel taunts whenever they go out. Despite the couple getting together when Lauren was , Bill was targeted online by close friends who called him Jimmy Savile, while strangers have accused him of liking children. But the couple have refused to let the comments affect them and insist theyaposre happier than ever. Lauren, a stay-at-home mum, says: Since Bill and I got together, we have dealt with a lot of judgement. But we have learned to laugh it off and it has only made us stronger.  Bill is the love of my le and I know weaposre made for each other. In September , Lauren met Bill, a retired crane operator, at a local karaoke night. Lauren says: Bill was wriggling his hips and dancing before he came over to introduce himself. I was only  and I guessed he was around . Even though he was much older, I realised we both loved music, fancy dress and singing. We were so similar. Over the next few years, Lauren and Bill kept bumping into each other on nights out. Lauren says: I was living with my boyfriend at the time but I was really unhappy. Soon I began confiding in Bill and he was there for me. After a while, I finally ended my relationship. I needed a place to stay and Bill kindly offered.  The morning after I moved in, he told me heaposd fallen for me and kissed me. I wasnapost sure at first because of our age gap but as I got to know him more each day, my feelings grew. Weeks later, in February , Lauren and Bill became a couple. Lauren says: One month later, Bill was having a birthday party and it was then when realised I still didnapost know his age. He said he was turning . He was older than Iaposd originally thought. But I didnapost care. Shortly after, Lauren and Bill came clean about their relationship to their families. Lauren says: My parents were shocked at first.  My dad was especially wary and told me Bill was too old for me and that I could get any man I wanted. But thankfully when they met Bill a few weeks later, they loved him. After that, Bill told his five sons, from a previous marriage. As one of them was only two years younger than me, I was very nervous to meet them. But to my surprise, they welcomed me in with open arms. Despite Lauren and Bill having their familyaposs approval, they soon faced criticism from Billaposs friends. Lauren says: Bill and I went to the pub and one of his friends said aposPass the sick bucketapos and others laughed.  It was upsetting but Bill reassured me it was because they were jealous.Soon after, I got a Facebook message from a random woman saying that Bill had cheated on me with her.I broke down in tears and confronted Bill. Bill said it was all lies and it turned out the profile was fake. We realised it was one of Billaposs friends trying to split us up. It was so cruel. Weeks later, Lauren uploaded a photo of her and Bill on Facebook. Lauren says: One of his friends commented aposYou must be younger than all of his sons. Bill is like Jimmy Savile.apos I couldnapost believe sheaposd call Bill that. It was horrying. Bill and I cut her off for good.  But Lauren and Bill still receive comments from strangers. Lauren says: People around town constantly gawped at us whenever we held hands in public. Then one day, at the pub, a man called Bill a paedophile and said he must like kids. I snapped at him and said I was  and I was a grown adult. Thankfully the bouncer overheard and threw the man out. Another time a woman passed us on the street and said aposThat lady is with her grandad.apos Each time we had a mean comment, it only made Bill and I stronger. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The couple refused to let others ruin their relationship. In September , Bill proposed to Lauren while on holiday in Bulgaria. Six month later, in July , they tied the knot in front of their family and friends. Lauren says: Bill and I have been together for eight years now and we have a beautul baby girl, Emily-Rose, who is now one. Bill is constantly mistaken for Emily-Roseaposs grandad. But we laugh it off now. Bill is the best thing to ever happen to me and his age will never matter. title: covid infections rise third uk
story: :root Covid infections rise in a third of UK areas as new epicentre emerges - see full listOf the  local areas in the UK, have seen a week-on-week rise in rates, with Neath Port Talbot continuing to have the highest rate of all, with , new cases in the seven daysMore than a third of all local areas across the UK have seen a rise in Covid cases Image: Julian Hamilton Daily MirrorByIan JonesRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep  have seen a week-on-week rise in rates, with Neath Port Talbot continuing to have the highest rate of all, with , new cases in the seven days" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Coronavirus-Sat-Nov--.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" have seen a week-on-week rise in rates, with Neath Port Talbot continuing to have the highest rate of all, with , new cases in the seven days" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Coronavirus-Sat-Nov--.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" have seen a week-on-week rise in rates, with Neath Port Talbot continuing to have the highest rate of all, with , new cases in the seven days" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Coronavirus-Sat-Nov--.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsMore than a third of all local areas across the UK have seen a rise in Covid cases, with the highest rates in new epicentre Wales, according to the latest data. The figures, for the seven days to September , are based on the number of people who have tested positive for Covid- in either a lab-reported or rapid lateral flow test, by specimen date. The rate is expressed as the number of new cases per , people. Data for the most recent four dayshas been excluded as it is incomplete and does not reflect the true number of cases. Of the  local areas in the UK, have seen a week-on-week rise in rates, have seen a fall and two are unchanged.  The highest rates in the UK are all in Wales. Neath Port Talbot continues to have the highest rate of all, with , new cases in the seven days to September  - the equivalent of . per , people. This is up from . in the seven days to September . Merthyr Tydfil has the second highest rate, up from . to ., with  new cases. Rhondda Cynon Taf has the third highest rate, up from . to ., with , new cases. West Dunbartonshire has the highest rate in Scotland , Allerdale in Cumbria has the highest rate in Englandand Fermanagh  Omagh has the highest rate in Northern Ireland .It comes as the UK has recorded a further , cases cases and new  new deaths in a huge rise on last weekaposs figures.The number of deaths has increased in a week since last Thursday where  people lost their lives in just  hours. Cases have also risen by nerly , from last Thursday where , people had tested positive for the disease, compared to the , today.  In just  hours, Thursdayaposs statistics showed that  people had been admitted to hospital after contracting coronavirus - making a current total of ,.  of those patients are on ventilation beds. But the increase falls short of many expertsapos predictions on children ing to school this month. Professor of medicine at Oxford University, Sir John Bell, said the country is over the worst and things should be fine once winter has passed.While Dame Sarah Gilbert also told a Royal Society of Medicine webinar that viruses tend to become weaker as they spread, with Covid to resemble the common cold by the end of spring . The five UK areas with the biggest week-on-week rises are:  Rhondda Cynon TafKetteringStaffordVale of GlamorganFlintshire The list has been calculated by the PA news agency using data published on title: dark days 1970s plagued pub
story: :root When was Winter of Discontent  Pub closures and blackouts as UK risks new crisisDowning Street has insisted there will be noto the three-day week of the s Winter of Discontent amid crippling gas shortages - but mounting crises have unwelcome parallels with the troubled decadeRubbish piling up in Londons Leicester Square in December  Image: PAByAlex BellottiNews Features Writer:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsAs energy prices soar, supermarket shelves lie bare and inflation goes through the roof, the UK faces a wave of fresh problems going into winter.This week, Boris Johnsoninsisted there would be noto a s style aposthree-day weekapos amid fears that gas shortages could see the lights go out in thousands of homes.The Prime Minister said the Government was working flat out with energy companies to guarantee supply, with wholesale prices for gas surging  per cent since January and  per cent since August alone.The mass shortages have drawn grim comparisons to the s, when Downing Street imposed sweeping restrictions on businesses that slashed the amount of working days in a week to just three. It marked the start of a dark decade that culminated in the infamous aposWinter of Discontentapos, where industrial action left mountains of rubbish piled up in the streets and severe weather cut off access to entire towns.With commentators now warning the Government faces a similar season of turmoil, here is how Britain was thrust into chaos - and risks being so once more. Pubs shut and TV curbed in aposthree-day weekapos Rising inflation troubled the economy throughout the s and to tackle it, pay caps were imposed on major industries including coal mining. By the end of , workersapos average pay had fallen behind inflation and the National Union of Mineworkers held a national ballot on strikes. Get the biggest news delivered to your inbox.for the Mirroraposs free newslettersWhile the motion was not passed, an overtime ban was imposed that crippled the coal industry and forced prime minister Ted Heath to take drastic measures. At midnight on December , the Tory leader took the unprecedented step of introducing a three-day working week - meaning businesses could only operate for a maximum of three consecutive days. In scenes similar to lockdown, most pubs shut their doors, while even TV broadcasts were limited. The BBC and ITV implemented a staggered shutdown, shutting off at .pm in alternating nights. As blackouts hit the country, it was even speculated that the Army could be called in to haul coal and work at power stations. In January , the NUM upped the stakes by going on strike and Heath responded by calling a general election.Feeling Brits would side with the Government, the Conservatives ran with the campaign slogan aposWho governs Britain apos The move backfired, however, with Labour taking the most seats. Labouraposs Harold Wilson ed to power in a minority government and cemented a majority in a second election that October. The miners were granted a  per cent pay increase, but the wave of discontent spreading across Britain had just begun. aposWinter of Discontentapos saw rubbish pile up in Leicester Square In the winter of – there were widespread strikes by public sector trade unions against the Governmentaposs attempts to curb wage increases. With Jim Callaghan now prime minister, the Labour leadership was once again battling rapid inflation, but faced internal disputes over the pay caps from members committed to the partyaposs socialist roots.  By the end of , lorry drivers had gone on strike, driving the country to a halt just as temperatures plummeted. In the coldest winter for  years, freezing weather cut off access to towns, with local authorities struggling to clear roads blaming staff shortages. Even football was affected as an entire round of the FA Cup was postponed for the first time in its history. With more than , strikes erupting around Britain, grim images of the consequences flooded newspaper front pages. Refuse collectors refused to pick up bags of rubbish, which piled up in Leicester Square, while even gravediggers joined the walkout.Their actions were demonised in headlines like “Now They Won’t Let Us Bury Our Dead!” and last year one union official promised the Mirror never again - though insisted low-paid workers were treated like dogs”.  Returning from a Caribbean summit, Callaghanaposs insistence that the situation did not amount to mounting chaos was met with derision. The Sun ran a front page headlined aposCrisis, what Crisis apos and quoted Shakespeareaposs opening line from Richard III, aposNow is the winter of our discontentapos - a phrase that came to define the era. As Tory leader Margaret Thatcher won a wave of support for denouncing the scenes, Callaghan faced a vote of no confidence. Sweeping to victory, Thatcher set about clamping down on the unions, while Labour faced over a decade in the wilderness. Boris faces rising tide of fresh crisesToday, the Tory government faces a mounting number of crises that have led to claims they risk a fresh aposWinter of Disconentapos.Kwasi Kwarteng, the Business Secretary, has insisted there is no question of the lights going out as struggling energy suppliers remain locked in emergency talked with the Government.  “There will be no three-day working weeks or a throwback to the s,” he said. “Such thinking is alarmist, unhelpful and completely misguided.” In unwelcome parallels with the decade, however, inflation surged to  per cent in figures published last week, the highest since the beginning of . That will spark fears that rising prices will leave families behind as public sector wages are frozen and benefits are cut. It could also squeeze Bank of England interest rates, which have been rock-bottom for so long that much of the mortgage market is dependent on them staying that way.Meanwhile, a lorry driver shortage blamed on Brexit immigration rules has led the Government to slash legal requirements to become an HGV driver.Industry chiefs fear the issues could affect the supply of toys, turkeys and more over the Christmas season. Ian Wright, outgoing chief executive of the Food and Drink Federation, has also warned supply issues that hit supermarkets, Nandoaposs and McDonaldaposs are going to get worse as the labour market changes after Covid.Elsewhere, the end of furlough on September  is set to coincide with six million Brits being hit by a £-a-week cut in Universal Credit.With Boris Johnson currently away in New York for three days of meetings with world leaders, there will be plenty in his inbox upon his . As he touched down back in the UK, he might be wary of the phrase: Crisis, what crisis  Comment MORE ON Boris JohnsonPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dog unrecognisable after venomous spider
story: :root Dog "unrecognisable" after venomous spider bite causes severe eye swellingBlack Labrador pup Bonnie was on a walk with owners Lisa and Nick Bennett in Gateshead, when rapid swelling caused by a spider bite forced her eye to shut completelyBlack Labrador puppy Bonnie was unrecognisable after a spider bite caused facial swelling to shut her eye completely Image: Vets NowByKatie DickinsonRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Sep | commentsA dog was unrecognisable after a bite from a venomous spider caused swelling which completely covered her eye. Black Labrador Bonnie was left in searing pain when a spider - thought to be a  widow or similar - sank its fangs into her face while she was out on a walk. The -month-old pup was rushed for emergency treatment in Gateshead after her eye became so swollen it closed shut. Owners Lisa and Nick Bennett, who were visiting family, were terried that Bonnieaposs throat and windpipe might close up from the reaction.They searched online for urgent animal treatment and found Vets Now emergency clinic in Gateshead - where they took the increasingly distressed pooch, Chronicle Live reports. Bonnie also experienced vomiting and diarrhoea on her way. Attendant vet Konrad ran tests and concluded Bonnie had been bitten by a spider, and hooked her up to a drip. The bite happened five days previously while the couple were walking their pet near Redditch in Worcestershire. Konrad gave Bonnie an injection, put her under observation, and waited for the swelling to go down. Bonnieaposs condition improved quickly after the treatment and she was soon well enough to be reunited with her relieved family. Lisa said: “It was a terrible shock to see her face swell up and it happened so quickly. “Being so far from home made it even worse — you just feel so vulnerable when your pet is in distress. “Bonnie is a very intelligent dog and she was clearly aware that something was wrong. “She kept trying to use her paw to wipe and scratch away the swelling, which made it more upsetting to see. “We assumed it was a reaction to something she’d eaten or possibly a snake bite, but it never occurred to us she’d been bitten by a spider. “Konrad and the team at Vets Now said it can be several days before a spider bite starts affecting a dog — and that’s when we realised. “Five days before all this drama happened, we’d been walking Bonnie and our other black lab Benson near our house when she gave a yelp and came limping back to us. “We checked her over, couldn’t see anything untoward and just assumed she’d maybe stood on a thorn. “Then she went off again and seemed totally fine. “But what we know now is that the yelp was almost certainly a sign she’d been bitten.”Senior vet nurse Ashley Wemple said it’s very rare for pets to be bitten by spiders.She added: “This is not the type of case we see every day. Butyour dog gets bitten by an insect or even a snake, it can be dficult to see any evidence because the bite is often covered by their fur. “Symptoms can include swelling, itchiness and irritation of the skin and, in severe cases, an allergic reaction. “It can take hours — or, as in Bonnie’s case, days — for this to happen. “Butthere is a bad reaction or swelling then time really is of the essence, and you should seek help straight away. “Nick and Lisa did the right thing calling us when they did —they had delayed, the consequences could have been very serious. “Bonnie was such a friendly and good-natured dog. We were all delighted to see her go back to Lisa and Nick after treatment with her tail wagging.” After three days there was no longer any trace of swelling on Bonnieaposs face - and she made a full recovery. Lisa said: “The service we got was brilliant from the moment we rang — and Konrad and his colleagues were so incredibly kind and patient, not just with Bonnie but with us as well. We’re really grateful to them for looking after her, and us, so well.” Comment MORE ON AnimalsSpidersFalse widow spidersBig DogsDogs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news exact-date-you-should-turn-"Martin Lewis gives Brits advice on the energy bill crisisBySophie LawAdvance Content Writer:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsAs temperatures start to drop and the days get shorter, you may be thinking itaposs almost time for you to put the heating on. But experts have revealed you should actually be waiting another month, when the clocks go back and the winter season really starts kicking in. As turning on your heating is a sure sign that winter has arrived central heating experts at PlumbNation have said you shouldnapost be switching it on any earlier than October . Expert Jordan Chance said: Turning on your central heating is notably one of the sure signs that winter has arrived.Although there is no single temperature at which you should turn your heating on, many aim for the time when clocks go back, falling this year on October st, he told the Daily Echo.  “There are, however, a series of ways to delay putting your heating on, keeping you warmer for longer and saving you those extra pennies. Using a draught excluder is one of the quickest and cheapest ways to keep your home warm, preventing cold air from entering and warm air from leaving under your doors.What do you think of this   Let us know in the comments below “Keeping your curtains closed, or investing in a thermal curtain lining can likewise help to prevent warm air from escaping - this trick alone can reduce heat loss by up to %. Whilst a favourite saying of parents is to ‘put a jumper on’, this old age argument can certainly keep you warmer for longer, and save the big switch on for a later date. It is also important to note that leaving your heating on low all day does not reduce your heating bills. Having the heating on only as and when you need it, is the best way to save energy. Using a thermostat with a timer offers a simple and speedy solution to controlling your heating effectively.” Top  tips to help you save money on heating . Upgrade Your Thermostat Your thermostat controls your home’s temperature by communicating with your boiler. Thermostats, particularly in older homes with older heating systems, can degrade over time. Such degradation can lead to delays in your boiler switching on, or your home being heated at much higher temperatures than required. Upgrading your thermostat could provide for greater accuracy in thermostat to boiler communication, preventing energy from being wasted, and saving you money. . Stop Draughts!  Stopping heat from escaping through unwanted gaps is one of the cheapest and most effective ways to save energy and money. To draught-proof your home, you need to primarily identy the ‘problem areas’ where draughts are causing issues, these could include doors, windows, chimneys and floorboards. You can block unwanted gaps by using draught-proofing strips around your windows and doors, or flexible silicone-based filler to fill the gaps in your floorboards. . Add an Extra LayerInstead of heating your home to be warm enough to walk around in shorts and a t-shirt, why not turn your thermostat down and put on a jumper  Adding clothing layers will insulate your body and make it easier to regulate your body’s temperature. The more layers you wear, the less the heating will need to be on, reducing your heating bills. . Introduce Soft Furnishings Soft furnishings, such as curtains and rugs, can make all the dference in saving money on your heating. If you have a carpeted home then it will naturally help to boost insulation however,you have hard flooring investing in some good quality materials, such as a plush rug, will help to prevent heat from being lost. . Turn Your Thermostat Down By °C  An excessive heating bill can be easily rectied with the ‘step-down’ challenge. By turning your heating down by just °C, you can save up to % on your heating bill. The typical heating range is between - °C - so why don’t you see how low you can go  It is also important to avoid classic thermostat ‘faux pas’. Contrary to popular belief, turning up your thermostat does not heat up your room quicker. This method will only send your energy bills skyrocketing. . Clean Your Radiators If your radiators aren’t in your weekly cleaning routine, then it’s time to add them. A buildup of dust can affect your health, allergies and your heating bill. Layers of dust in your radiator can prevent heat from escaping effectively, meaning your radiators will have to work harder to warm your room. . Don’t Dry Your Clothes On Your Radiator We would recommend that you stop using your radiators to dry your clothes. The clothes that you place over the top of your radiators prevent the heat from escaping and heating your room, meaning that your boiler has to pick up the slack and work at a greater rate - increasing costs. Similarly, the increase in the air’s moisture can create condensation, leading to potential issues with mould and dampness. . Check Your Radiator Cover If you have a radiator cover make sure to check that it is a good conductor of heat. Radiator covers made from materials such as wood are poor conductors and can prevent heat from being dispersed effectively - wasting energy and money. If your radiator cover has a solid top then you may be losing even more heat, as it will be absorbed by the top of the cover. . Bleed Your Radiators Bleeding your radiator is essential in preventing the efficiency of your radiator from decreasing, as a result of air entering your heating system. The quickest way to checkair has entered your heating system is to turn your central heating on and feel your radiator. If the radiator is warm at the bottom but cold at the top this is generally a sign that air is present. . Get Your Boiler Serviced If your boiler is ageing and has seen better days, there’s a strong chance it won’t be working as efficiently as it once was. Defective boilers can increase your heating bill massively as they will need to work signicantly harder to bring your home up to the desired temperature. We recommend that you get your boiler serviced every  months , to ensure that your boiler is running efficiently and safely. title: family defy 135000 one odds
story: :root Family defy ,-to-one odds to have three generations born on the same daySteven Hills granddaughter, Sophia Rose, was born in the early hours of Wednesday, September , following in the footsteps of Stevens we, Pauline and his daughter LauraMum, Pauline, with daughter, Laura, and her new baby Sophia Rose Image: Liverpool EchoByMirror:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThree generations of a single family all share the same birthday. Steven Hillaposs granddaughter, Sophia Rose, was born in the early hours of Wednesday, September .Stevenaposs we, Pauline, , was also born on September  in , and daughter Laura, , was born exactly -years apart on the same date in , Liverpool Echo reported. In making it three generations in a row the Hillaposs are one in ,.  Steven, from West Derby, Liverpool, said that buying presents will be even more of a challenge following Sophiaaposs birthday. Steven, , said: Iaposve just got aposhappy birthday motherapos, aposhappy birthday daughterapos, and aposhappy birthday granddaughterapos balloons.  My daughter was given the same due date as my we, which was the th. Months ago my we said sheaposll have it on our birthday, guaranteed. She just made it by two and a half hours. Laura gave birth to her second child, lb oz Sophia Rose at .am at the Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital.  Steve said: Since Laura was born, my we never had a proper birthday as Laura always takes centre stage because sheaposs the daughter. And now weaposve said to Laura, now the new baby is going to take it over you, so youaposre going to have to deal with what your mum had to deal with for years. Steve said he had planned to have a meal out with his we and daughter to celebrate their joint birthday, but that the plan was only pencilled in on the off-chance she went into labour on her birthday. Despite having to fork out for three gts on one day from now on, Steve is overjoyed by the new family arrival and fully intended to wet the babyaposs head tonight. Speaking of the birthday coincidence, he added: I knew I should have put a bet on. We also have a pet Yorkie who is nine and his birthday is also on the nd of September. title: fed up man puts up
story: :root Fed-up man builds fence round house to stop chippy customers peering into living roomStephen Williams put up the ft-high picket fence to block off a path and a layby used by customers going into the chippy next doorStephen Williams used to run a sweet shop next to Victoria House Fish and Chips, but is now turning the old shop into a living room Image: SWNSByBradley Stokes:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA man in search of some privacy from chippy customers sitting on his window sill and peering into his living room has erected a fence around the footpath around his house. Stephen Williams put up the ft-high picket fence to block off a path and a layby used by customers going into the chippy next door. The -year-old used to run a sweet shop next to Victoria House Fish and Chips, which he was forced to close in . He has held onto the property and has now transformed the building into a house. The old shop front is being turned into a living room but customers are furious, saying pedestrians must now walk on the road to get to the chip shop. Thereaposs a layby outside the chippy which people use to park before picking up their food,” one customer said.  The chip shop has been there for years. Whoever bought the house next door must have known that. Sticking a fence up is very petty.” The customer went on to say it was “unbelievable” that Williams wants privacy now, after benefiting from people walking on the path when they were coming into his shop and “lining his pockets”. Mr Williams built the fence along the original boundary line of his £, semi-detached property in Alnwick, Northumberland, which extends ft onto the layby. A nearby resident said that while they didn’t agree with the fence, they had some sympathy for Williams.  Stephen is sick and tired of people eating their chips right outside his home,” they said. Sometimes schoolkids queue outside and can go right outside his living room window. They are basically sitting on his windowsill stuffing their faces while heaposs watching TV. Council chiefs are now investigatingMr Williamsapos fence is legal. Cllr Gordon Castle, Alnwick ward member for Northumberland County Council, said he had raised it with officers at County Hall to the highest level. He [Mr Williams] claims to have deeds showing ownership of where his fence now sits,” Cllr Castle said. I can hardly believe he has gone ahead with this before any resolution with county highways, especially given the impact on pedestrians and children walking to school. There are meetings scheduled to find the legal way forward and Iaposm sorry I canapost do more, but Iaposve sent photos and explained to officers that Iaposm receiving many messages of complaint. I canapost get it higher or faster at County Hall, but I wonapost let it go. Mr Williams defended the fence, saying he wanted privacy now that the shop had been turned into a house and the front room had become his living room. This means the window faces straight onto the path which is used by people queuing to get fish and chips,” he said. Weaposve had people eating their chips on our windowsill and looking through the window while we are trying to relax. Itaposs not on. We just want some privacy. The land is rightfully ours. We checked with the plans and we are legally entitled to put a fence up. Most people wouldnapost want people using their land as a footpath and neither do we. We just want to protect our property. title: five tricks rid fruit flies
story: :root Five tricks to get rid of fruit flies as warm weather sees insects invade homesFruit flies usually swarm UK homes during early autumn - but this years hot weather, paired with increased rainfall, has led to a surge in insect breedingHere are five clever zero-waste tips and tricks to help banish fruit flies from your home Image: HereByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Sep | commentsSwarms of fruit flies have been invading UK homes in search of rotting morsels - so here are five environmentally-friendly ways of keeping them out.Early autumn typically marks a rise in a range of creepy crawlies, including fruit flies.The bugs can lay as many  eggs during their short lespan, making them extremely hard to control.While they may seem like harmless pests, they can carry germs and bacteria such as salmonella, E. coli and listeria. They also attract more spiders into our homes.There are plenty of products to help tackle flies in the home, but they usually damage the environment. Fly tape is wrapped in useless packaging and is a common hazard for pets who get it caught in their fur. While fly spray may seem like the go-to option, itaposs well known for containing toxins - a hazard for not only our pets but for plants and humans too. Here are five ways of banishing fruit flies from your home - without causing unnecessary damage to your home or the environment. . Homemade fly tape  While store bought fly tape may seem like an easy and effective option, itaposs packaged in unnecessary plastic and cardboard. You can make your own version at home with simple materials. Thick Paper cut into inch wide strips can be used for the tape - opt to reuse old packaging that would otherwise be thrown away. To make your sticky coating, mix honey, sugar, and warm water until it forms a gloopy solution. Submerge the pre-cut strips in the mixture, and leave these to dry. Lastly, attach string to the top of each and hang around the house as needed. . Wine trap  If you have leftover wine hanging around which has gone bad, you can use this to trap pesky flies. All you need to do is leave an almost empty wine bottle open in the affected room. Fruit flies are attracted to alcohol, they will simply fly in and be unable to escape up the neck of the bottle. Don’t have wine  Don’t worry. Other alcohol such as beer works just as well. Just make sure your chosen beverage is in a funnel neck bottle. Alternatively, you can pour the liquid into a bowl, cover and add holes . Apple cider vinegar trap  The sweetness of the apple cider vinegar lures in fruit flies in the same way wine does. To create your trap, fill a container with vinegar but add in a few drops of dish soap - and place in the infested area. The soap works to break the surface tension of the vinegar, leaving the flies to drown and sink to the bottom. As a result, you don’t need to use any cling film or other single use plastics for this option. . Old fruit  If you have old fruit lying around, this could be the source of your infestation. But, you can use pieces of it to trap and eradicate the flies. Once you have some chunks of overripe fruit, put them in the bottom of a glass jar and add a little vinegar for added effectiveness. Lastly, take some paper and roll this into a cone, put it in the top of the jar to create a funnel. The rotting fruit will attract the fruit flies, but the cone means they will be unable to escape. . Use essential oils  There are some scents which fruit flies hate, and which can be utilised to keep them out of your home. Basil, lemongrass, peppermint, and lavender are all well known to deter fruit flies. Try placing basil plants around the home to deter the insects - you can then cook with them to ensure zero waste. Alternatively try the other scents as essential oils either in a burner or spray form, they’ll keep fruit flies away and leave your home smelling fresh.According to waste collection company Skips and Bins, itaposs easier to prevent the infestation than to get rid of one.Methods to keep the bugs at bay include planning consumption of fresh fruit and veg to ensure pieces of rotten fruit donapost become a beacon to the pests. Managing Director, Scott Hawthorne, said: “It’s worth pointing out that preventing fruit flies is often much easier than getting rid of them. Fruit flies often appear when there is rotting produce in our homes. To avoid this happening try to plan ahead and only buy as much fresh produce as you need, eliminating the chance for any forgotten fruit and vegetables to rot in your kitchen. It’s important to monitor your cupboards and fridge to catch food before it goes bad. There’s plenty of optionsyou have excess fruit and vegetables. Try turning these into soups, cakes, ice lollies or freezing where possible to avoid wastage. If all  fails, try keeping fruit in the fridge rather than uncovered on a counter, regularly clean drains and bins, and wash dishcloths often.” Comment MORE ON AppleAlcoholFood poisoningAnimalsSalmonellaInsects" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news genius-two-year-old-who-"Genius two-year-old learns how to count to  in Japanese in less than  hoursByZoe ForseyFeatures EditorTfany Wallis:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsIsaiah Gyamfi may only be two years old, but he can already ready, write, count in English, Spanish and French and solve multiplication and subtraction math problems. And now the genius tot has impressed yet again by learning how to count up to  in Japanese in less than  hours. Proud mum Jazelle, , from South West London, tells the Mirror Isaiah has been able to grasp new information extraordinarily easily from the age of five months. The early years teacher explains: “One day Isaiah was watching a phonic video on my phone on YouTube, he scrolled to the videos at the bottom and clicked on a Japanese numeracy video. “He listened to it once and was fixated. He asked to watch it again, then before I knew it he would recite the numbers back to back. “I knew then he was keen on languages, so I showed him a video in Spanish. His eyes lit up, so I decided to buy him Spanish flashcards he absolutely loved these and would study them every day. “He loves that Japanese has a pattern. Once you learn numbers -, it’s very easy to learn the rest. Japanese numbers follow a logical pattern, with a few exceptions. “So, it’s a continuous repeat of the same word for dferent numbers. For example, number  is ‘ichi’ and number  is ‘juu’….. therefore, number  would be juu-ichi. “Because plus is . Simply place the  words together and you’ll have . There’s only a few exceptions. It’s so cool once you get the hang of it!” When Isaiah was just four-months old, Jazelle turned her living room into a numeracy and literacy environment so that Isaiah could benefit visually. When Isaiah was eight-months-old, Jazelle would ask him questions, ‘whereaposs the letter H  Or S  - then incredibly, Isaiah would point out the correct letters. Weeks after he would sound them out using phonics. Jazelle said: “I was first taken back and thought, did my eight-month-old just call out letters  I remember just laughing nervously but I was so excited and wanted to hear it again. “I thought maybe it sounded like he said the numbers and letters but he actually said something . But he continued to say it which confirmed what I thought. “I remember telling his dad when he got home from work I took Isaiah to the wall where the letter and number stickers were, when he called them out we both stood there just laughing. “We were first time parents and just felt so proud and excited.” The mum said she did think it was unusual but admitted she was overjoyed more than anything  - and noticed that her son was also excited. She added Isaiah enjoys having numbers in front of him and loves practising alone he has white boards, and pens to practise writing numbers every day. Jazelle said: “When I realised he was identying numbers and letters I bought him a pack of sight words. I actually placed them in a drawer and thought he wouldnapost be interested.  “But I started reading them to him, incorporating the phonics, and he showed interest in this and would flick through them “A while after this I thought to see how much he remembered, so I flashed a card and said “what does this say ”, to my surprise he got each one correct! “With multiplication, he would write numbers - on his board, he’d skip count by s, simply by missing out a number. This was and still is his favourite activity to do.” She added: “I recall one of his nursery teachers telling me that he sat with his friends and helped them learn their numbers. “She said his friends werenapost so confident, so Isaiah sat with them and would point out the numbers, asking them to repeat what he was saying. “She said how sweet it was to see, and how much he wanted everyone to learn with him. It was a moment I won’t forget. He was just over two at the time.” After turning one, Isaiah would air write letters before getting a doodle pad which he then wrote numbers on.Other parents didnapost believe Isaiah’s capabilities, so Jazelle began to document his learning through footage and share it on her popular Instagram page.Jazelle said you only have to see her son’s face when he is around numbers to realise that’s when he is at his happiest. The mum said: “I have had an amazing response from people. I’d say % of people have rooted for him and praised him along the way. “Some ask for tips and some just say how they find him amazing. However, I received a handful of people saying, ‘he’s just a kid, let him play, he shouldn’t be learning like this. “But what they don’t understand is, Isaiah wakes up and WANTS to learn. All of what you see is all child led. “He loves to ask so many questions and is so loving. He’s also very head strong and passionate about learning. It blows my mind because he is only two-years-old. “I have never had experience with a child like him, and I’m saying that with over  years experience in early years education. “We are currently on the hunt for an educational psychologist to assess Isaiah as we believe he is a child of high potential and upon research, could be gted. “It’s frustrating to know that some think I’m a pushy parent, but that can’t be further from the truth. Isaiah is unique, he finds learning extremely exciting, and perceives it as play. “He is happy and that’s all that matters to me!”Do you have a story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplc.Comment MORE ON Parenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: gp explains brits having worst
story: :root GP explains why Brits having worst cold ever as people mix after  months of CovidLondon GP Dr Philippa Kaye says the "worst cold ever" is hitting Brits hard this autumn because two years of dodging Covid has left us with lower immunity to the virusesTwo years of dodging Covid has left Brits without immunity to common coughs, cold and flu viruses Image: Getty ImagesByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA GP has explained why Brits are suffering with severe bouts of the common cold this autumn. Thousands of people Brits are reporting symptoms that could be easily mistaken for Covid. Negative results show they are suffering instead with a harmless but nasty common cold infection.Dr Philippa Kaye, a GP at a London practice, told BBC Newsbeat : Weaposve actually been seeing a rise in the number of coughs and colds and viral infections.We are mixing in a way that we havenapost been mixing over the past  months. The spike in viral infections come as the public s to normality -with less stress now on mask wearing and social distancing as Brits head back to work or school. New arrivals at universities also face a spike in Fresheraposs Flu - an increase in viral symptoms as students bring viruses from their own towns to their lecture halls, Wales Online reports.Rebecca London, , from Bournemouth told the BBC she caught a cold at a festival and it was aposthe worst everapos. She said: I barely slept, Iaposd wake up in the night just coughing, a constantly runny nose and feeling so tired. The cold lasted more than a week, she said. Noor Hashmi, , another student, told the BBC: Normally Iaposm still able to go about my day, but this one left me with muscle fatigue, a lost voice and headache that meant Iaposve just stayed indoors. Dr Philippa advises people experiencing symptoms of Covid - like a new cough, fever, loss of sense of taste or smell - to take a PCR test. Cold symptoms can be treated with rest, fluids and over-the-counter painkillers, she adds. Following Covid prevention measures - like wearing masks and social distancing - means weaposve missed the chance to develop immunity to coughs, cold and flu viruses for two years. As your body has not had the opportunity to fight the illnesses, when they reach you the symptoms can be worse.Dr Ron Eccles, Emeritus Professor at Cardf Universityaposs School of Biosciences told Patient.info : If youaposve been exposed to a particular virus before, you may not develop any symptoms at all, because your immune system has been primed to fight off the infection.Itaposs the same process that means you usually only catch chickenpox once. With common colds we generally donapost have such a strong immune response and therefore we probably donapost get lelong immunity to a particular virus, he adds. However, we may get a milder responsewe are exposed to that virus again. The NHSaposs big three symptoms for Covid are a high temperature which leaves your back or chest feeling hot, a new, continuous cough, and a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste. If you experience any of these symptoms then get a PCR test and self-isolate until you get your test result. title: house cornwall holiday hotspot market
story: :root House in Cornwall holiday hotspot on the market for just £, – but comes with wheelsThe property currently located in Falmouth, Cornwall, is built on a trailer and can be attached to a car and driven aroundA tiny house built on wheels is up for sale - for £K Image: DeeGee PHOTO   SWNSByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Sep | commentsA house in a popular holiday hotspot is on the market for just £, and boasts two bedrooms – but no fixed location. The property currently located in Falmouth, Cornwall, is built on a trailer and can be attached to a car and driven around. It has a wooden frame and metal exterior and on the inside, contains everything a regular home might, including two bedrooms, a fully-ing bathroom, living room and kitchen. Creator, Chris Metcalf, believes the “unique” property offers an “innovative” solution to the UK’s housing crisis and would make an ideal choice for guests or teenagers. The home’s advert reads: “The Tiny House On Wheels is a locally made, unique and innovative housing solution. Built on top of a purpose-built steel chassis for ease of transporting to its forever home, the Tiny House is ideal for additional guest accommodation, a den for teenagers, or even a work from home study. Popular with buyers looking for an additional Air B  B type income, the Tiny House On Wheels can be parked on private landand mains Electrics and water hook up capability. The Tiny House has everything you need for comfortable day-to-day living, with a fully fitted kitchen and bathroom, a double bedroom, and a single bedroom. The Tiny House is both stylish and finished to a high specication and is to be sold complete with fixtures and fittings.” Mr Metcalf, an electrician, spent more than a year building the home - which is advertised on Rightmove. He said: “I think it’s a really cool idea. There’s a shortage of properties in the South West at the moment. “Families who might want extra accommodation, but don’t want to or can’t buy a bigger house or move home - this would be ideal.aposapos Comment MORE ON property news" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts from our Property Market newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: how hot your town like
story: :root How hot does your town like it  The nations spice preferences revealed... Are you a heat-loving West Midlander  Or perhaps a more chilli-wary east of England resident  Our survey reveals which areas in the UK are partial to a bit of spiceAbstract luxury soft Red background Christmas Valentines layout design,studio,room, web template ,Business report with smooth circle gradient colorAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep  We all know that KFC ’s Popcorn Chicken is practically a national treasure – crunchy, moreish, delicious little pops of  per cent chicken breast – but here’s some news: IT JUST GOT SPICY. For a limited time, it’s acquired an edge, a kick, a fiery twist to tantalise your tastebuds. Introducing the Zinger Popcorn Bucket.Trialled in ten lucky locations in April, it proved so popular it’s now officially launching across the UK, so that everyone can feel the burn! But where are the spice fiends who’ll be going straight off to order it, and which of us Brits are more chary with the chilli  SPICE UP YOUR LIFE KFC surveyed the nation’s spice preferences, asking residents in Northern Ireland, Wales, Scotland, London, the North East, North West, Yorkshire, East Midlands, West Midlands, East of England, South East and South West how spicy they like their food. The results show that it’s Londoners who have the biggest appetite for heat:  per cent of those in the capital said they like their food to be nice and spicy or even to feel their mouths on fire. The Scots and West Midlanders are runners-up in their love of the burn, at  and  per cent respectively. But spice is off the menu in Yorkshire: around one in five people declared that they prefer their food mild – the highest number of any region surveyed. Hot on their heelswere those in the East of England. The survey also revealed the gap between people’s estimation of their own region’s appetite for spice and the reality. Residents of Northern Ireland were widest off the mark, guessing that only  per cent would like fiery food, whereas the true figure was  per cent. In contrast,  per cent of those in the North West thought their population would love serious spice, but it was actually a mere  per cent. London and the West Midlands came out top when people were asked which region they thought would have the greatest penchant for spicy food, and they were broadly right. But those in the South West were wrongly assumed to have the least tolerance for the tingle factor. And what about you  Can you take the heat  If you’re a dance-till-dawn, touch-of-the-hedonist kind of person who loves food that makes your eyes widen and your tongue take notice, the Zinger Popcorn Bucket is your order of dreams. If you get your kicks from breaking in your new lambswool slippers in front of Call the Midwe, and your flavour frisson comes from a sprinkling of parsley... maybe not so much. The Zinger Popcorn Bucket is only here until October , so now’s the time to find outyou can handle the heat!Download the app, head in store or order online. title: how long you left life
story: :root How long do you have left  Le expectancy calculator works out when youre expected to dieLe expectancy ies from place to place, so how much longer could you expect to live  Using the link below enter your information and postcode to find outWomen in the UK are on average expected to live until the age of , and men  Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA le expectancy calculator has shared when youaposre expected to die - how long do you have left to live  For men in the UK it has fallen for the first time in  years, the Office for National Statistics says. At birth in the three years prior to , it was  years for men, falling back to a level last seen in -. Female le expectancy was virtually unchanged, at just below . Use the link below to enter your information and postcode to find out your predicted le expectancy based on where you live. Figures looking at deprivation lag behind the most up to date stats, and are due out in March - but those available show a growing ide. The figures from - show a north south ide, with the shorter lives of people in the north getting shorter, and the longer lives of those in south - particularly the South West - generally getting longer. The gap at that time was . years for males and . years for females. Between local authorities, Glasgow was lowest at . years for women , . fewer years than Kensington and Cha , which was up from . years, so as a proxy for rich and poor, that gaps definitely growing. For men, again, Glasgow was lowest at . years , . fewer years than Westminster , which was up from . years. ONS statistician Pamela Cobb said: “Le expectancy has increased in the UK over the last  years, albeit at a slower pace in the last decade. “This is the first time we have seen a decline when comparing non-overlapping time periods since the series began in the early s.” The ONS calculates that a boy born between  and  is expected to live until he is  years oldcurrent trends stay the same. Before the pandemic le expectancy in the UK was increasing, although at a much slower rate after  compared with previous decades. Some analysis suggested it had tipped in to reverse in less wealthy area of the country following a decade of Tory austerity policies. However this is the first full multi-year period where the NHS has been able to confirm this. David Finch, assistant director at the Health Foundation, said: “While we would hope to see some bounce back in le expectancy as the country recovers from the pandemic, there is a risk that, without a focus on improving health, we willto the slow progress we saw in the s. “Today’s data also provides further evidence of growing dferences in health between local areas with gaps between the best and worst areas expanding for both men and women.”  Glasgow City had the lowest le expectancy at birth at . years for men and . years for women. Even at the start of the millennium the best performing local areas exceeded this by  years. Areas with the highest le expectancy were both in London with Westminster coming top for men at . years and Kensington and Cha for women at . years. Le expectancy had been steadily rising for both men and women since the ONS first began collecting comparable data in -. Then a newborn boy was expected to live for . years, while a woman would live on average for . years. Separate Oxford University research indicates the Covid- pandemic saw le expectancy fall across most of Europe and the USA in , on a scale not seen since the World War Two. Author Dr Ridhi Kashyap, associate professor of social demography, said: “This is something that we really don’t have since World War Two for most of Western Europe - and since the dissolution of the Soviet Union, in the s, in Eastern Europe.” Pamela Cobb, of the ONS, added: “Demographers commonly refer to these changes in le expectancy as improvements as we have become accustomed to le expectancy increasing over time, albeit at a notably slower rate in the last decade.“The coronavirus pandemic does not mean that we are going to live shorter lives on average, or that we might not expect ato improvements in le expectancy in the future.“But we will have to wait to see what the longer-term trend looks like when we emerge from the pandemic.” Comment MORE ON NHSOffice for National StatisticsHealth Trust Inc.Le expectancy" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
