title: iceland boss announces staff boxing
story: :root Iceland boss announces all staff will get Boxing Day off and warns of supply shortagesAfter an audience member, also a retail manager, asked about time off over the festive period Icelands Richard Walker confirmed he was planning on giving staff the day offThe exchange took place on BBC Question Time on Thursday Image: BBCByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThe boss of supermarket retailer Iceland has let slip that the company will be giving its staff a day off for Boxing Day this year. Richard Walker appeared on BBCaposs Question Time on Thursday night when he answered a question about the dficulties the industry is facing. After an audience member, also a retail manager, asked about time off over the festive period he confirmed the food retailer was planning on giving its staff the day off. He admitted he was revealing the news a week ahead of a formal company announcement. During the exchange a member of the public said: We have been talking a lot about the delivery issues, Iaposm a store manager in retail and have been for a number of years and itaposs incredibly dficult at the moment.  Last Christmas was really challenging with the lockdowns, everything closing. This year already we are facing dficulties getting products on the shelves. Isnapost it about time that for all retailers to allow their teams to have time off on Boxing Day for the first time  I just think that really should just be a thing for all retailers. I know some big names have already announced it. Surely you guys on the  can do something about that to allow us to spend time with our friends, and our family, after working such an intense period through Christmas. There was a large round of applause from the audience after the question. Answering him Iceland managing director Richard Walker let slip an announcement was set to be made next week about allowing time off.  He said: You havenapost had the option to work from home, unlike most industries, and youaposre right, itaposs a very tough job that is getting tougher. Asked by Fiona Brucehe would like to see the member of the public get Boxing Day off he answered aposyes.apos Before moving to the next question he added: Iaposve just scuppered an announcement for next week I think. He went on to confirm that the company was planning on allowing the day off, prompting another round of applause. It comes after Mr Walker warned that food could run low in supermarkets long before Christmas in a stark warning. He said earlier that food shortages could happen in just weeks. He said: This is no longer about whether or not Christmas will be OK, itaposs about keeping the wheels turning and the lights on so we can actually get to Christmas. This could become a problem over the coming days and weeks, so this is not an issue thataposs months away. He added that Iceland was stocking up on items such as frozen meat, which is already at risk of running low. He added: I think there will be problems before Christmas. No one has a problem just at the moment but it could become a problem over the coming days and weeks. It is not an issue that is months away. Other supermarkets have already announced closures for Boxing Day. Morrisons was the first supermarket to confirm its stores will be shut on Boxing Day this year. Sainsburyaposs also said it would be shut. Aldi will shut all its  shops on Boxing Day, as it has done in previous years, as will Home Bargains. Marks and Spencer also announced it would be shut, giving , staffers the day off. news uk-news i-groomed--neighbour--"The Salvation Army: Woman discusses being kept as a sex slaveByAlex BellottiNews Features Writer:,  Sep Dressed in her primary school unorm, Jenny* often stopped at her neighbouraposs house to play with his dog in the front garden. Over time, the young girl struck up a friendship with the petaposs -year-old owner, Keith, who began giving her lts to school and lavishing her with gts. With a dad who walked out on her while still young and a mum who worked around the clock to make ends meet, Jenny spent a lot of time alone and was grateful to know a friendly face. Aged , however, Keith started asking for sexual favours. It marked the beginning of a horric journey that saw the vulnerable teenager sold as a sex slave to forceful and violent men - and plied with booze and drugs. I realised it was wrong when he started to say Iaposve done this for you, what are you going to do for me  I said I didnapost want to, Jenny says now of her neighbouraposs sick abuse. He said it would only take a couple of seconds and I was special to him - and thathe was special to me and I appreciated what he did Iaposd have sex. I think from the first time thataposs when he felt he owned you or made his mark on you. Perv neighbour invited men to abuse young girl Horrendously abused for years, Jenny eventually reached out for help and called The Salvation Army, whose workers took her to a safe house within two hours and gave her invaluable support. Now, she is speaking out about her experience ahead of a skye with another survivor of modern slavery to raise money for the charitable organisation. Get the biggest news delivered to your inbox.for the Mirroraposs free newslettersI got to know Keith when I went to primary school, she explains in a video. I was in Year Six, and he had a dog so on the way to school youaposd pet the dog. He was always around so it was just a good morning and a friendly face. It was just nice to have someone so interested. Heaposd invite you in the house for a drink and heaposd put his hand on your knee and it was uncomfortable, but it sort of progressed from there. Jenny explains she was afraid to tell her family about the abuse, and over time Keith demanded more and more aposfavoursapos.  One day, he told her he was in debt to other men, whom he began inviting over to his house to join in the vile abuse. Theyaposd offer you weed, theyaposd offer you drugs, theyaposd offer you alcohol, and they were a lot more forceful and violent, says Jenny. Theyaposd pass you around. The men would then bring their friends in and then the network got bigger. aposTrafficking steals your identityapos Addicted to the drug diazepam, Jenny left home aged  and stayed at a womenaposs refuge. However, after years of emotional abuse, she struggled to tear herself free from her tormentors.  I kept going back, she says. You can try and run away but trafficking almost steals your identity. So you become what theyaposve made you become. Thataposs all you feel worth so you go back because thataposs the only thing giving you purpose. Thankfully, after being put in touch with Victim Support by the police, she was told to ring The Salvation Army. The group provides specialist support for adult victims of modern slavery in England and Wales, working with a network of partners running safe houses and outreach support. If it wasnapost for that phone call, andit wasnapost for The Salvation Army, I wouldaposve been dead by now, says Jenny. They didnapost ask questions, they didnapost judge you, they didnapost put any pressure on you. You just felt free and safe.Have you been a victim of modern slavery and want to share your story  Get in touch by emailing alex.bellotti@reachplcJenny and Dan*, a fellow modern slavery survivor, are planning their jump on Sunday,  October, the day before Anti-Slavery Day – which aims to raise awareness of the plight of slavery survivors and the warning signs people can look out for. They hope their skye will encourage others to sign up to take the leap for The Salvation Army so that more funds can be raised to help support the organisation’s work. Forced to sell drugs by aposthreateningapos bosses Dan was support by the organisation after bosses at a warehouse he was working at began forcing him to sell drugs - threatening his family and refusing to pay him for his long shts. When the police raided the warehouse, they realised he was a victim and took him to a safe house where The Salvation Army and its partners helped him to recover from his ordeal. Speaking about the groupaposs support, Dan says: “I was always treated with respect, honesty and integrity. I learned so much - from cooking skills to languages and other cultures - and their positive energy would instantly cheer me up whenever I felt down. They also helped me apply for work and my confidence grew under their care. Amazing people who deserve recognition. What an amazing service. I will forever be in their debt.”Kathy Betteridge, director of anti-trafficking and modern slavery for The Salvation Army, says: “We are so grateful to Jenny and Dan and in awe of their bravery in skying to raise vital funds for our work with modern slavery survivors.“Please do donate to support their jump via their Just Giving link, but you could consider taking the leap yourself to raise funds for The Salvation Army so that we can continue to help people who have gone through unimaginable experiences on their journey of recovery.” *Names have been changed To donate to the work of The Salvation Army support with modern slavery survivors and support Jenny and Dan in their skye click here. news uk-news im-celeb-people-baffled-how-"It Confused Ant  Dec But How Would You Pronounce It ByMillie ReevesBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Sep | comments‘Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch’ is perhaps the most famous Welsh village name, but it’s not the only one that non-Welsh speakers struggle with. Presenting duo Ant and Dec have left people making all kinds of attempts to pronounce another location after snapping a photo on their way to the I’m a Celeb filming spot.The pair once struggled to pronounce Gwrych Castle, which is near Abergele, where the show was filmed last year, Chill reports.And en route to the venue where the show will be filmed for , the presenters stopped off at Mynyddislwyn, which left UK fans pondering the correct pronunciation. Even Ant and Dec looked baffled - but that may be because they were  miles out of their way after taking a wrong turn at Newport.  So here’s all you - and Ant and Dec - need to know about Mynyddislwyn and how to pronounce it like a local with a quick Welsh lesson.How do you say it Don’t stumble at the first hurdle - the ‘y’ in the first part of the word. It’s pronounced like aposughapos. aposDdapos in Welsh is classed as its own letter and is pronounced aposthapos. Another confusion comes with aposwyapos that makes an aposooapos. But let’s make it easy for you - put it all together and you get mun-ith-is-loo-in.Wondering where to eat, drink or visit for your next UK holiday  At Chill we help you decide where to go and stay next with hundreds of recommendations right on your doorstep. Visit our brilliant new website chill and start packing. If youaposd also like weekly inspiration and advice for your next trip, you can sign up to the Chill newsletter here. For the latest must-have travel news follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter.What does it mean anyway Mynydd means mountain in Welsh and the parish is often translated as aposmountain ashapos or aposmountain below the groveapos. There is actually a place called Mountain Ash not too far away, so donapost get them mixed up.Where is it exactly Mynyddislwyn is a small parish between Ystrad Mynach and Crumlin and while technically in Monmouthshire, itaposs more aligned to Caerphilly. So people there claim it as theirs, whatever the internet might say.And what about Gwrych Castle  Any help on how to say that According to researcher at Gwrych Castle Preservation Trust, Rhŷn Williams, the impressive Welsh castle is in fact pronounced, Goo-rreech. He said the stress on the aposWapos part is paramount. *That’s ‘welcome back’ in Welsh! news uk-news kate-middleton-dons-tennis-gear-"Kate Middleton meets Emma RaducanuByJenner Newton:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge has met with teenage tennis sensation Emma Raducanu to congratulate her on her stunning US Open win - and got competitive by going up against her on court.The -year-old met with Kate Middleton at the Lawn Tennis Associationaposs National Tennis Centre in London, where they teamed up for a doubles game before going head-to-head against each other.And it was even remarked that it was getting competitive.Kate came dressed for the occasion in a navy tennis skirt and tracksuit top and also brought her racket along with her. As well as meeting Emma, Kate also chatted with fellow British US Open champions Joe Salisbury, who won the menaposs doubles title with American Rajeev Ram, and Gordon Reid and Alfie Hewett, the menaposs wheelchair doubles champions. There was an awkward moment when Kate first arrived as she was unsure how to congratulate the group.She said: Are we shaking hands  I donapost want to break your training bubbles.Itaposs really awkward, you donapost know quite whether to do it. It is the same with face masks.You never know whether to hug people, congratulate them or shake hands. But amazing, guys honestly, congratulations.Emma, who is now ranked nd in the world, became the first qualier to win one of the four majors when she claimed the US Open womenaposs singles title earlier this month. She also became the first British woman in  years to win a Grand Slam title, when she breezed past Canadian Leylah Fernandez in straight sets.After her victory, Kate took to Twitter to send a rare personal tweet saying : Huge congratulations @EmmaRaducanu on your stunning performances and historic Grand Slam victory! Incredible –we are all so proud of you. @leylahfernandez well done on your amazing achievements at this year’s #USOpen, it’s been a pleasure to watch. CThe Queen also said it was a remarkable achievement at such a young age and added she was an inspiration for future tennis players. In a personal message to Emma, she said: I send my congratulations to you on your success in winning the United States Open Tennis Championships. It is a remarkable achievement at such a young age, and is testament to your hard work and dedication. I have no doubt your outstanding performance, and that of your opponent Leylah Fernandez, will inspire the next generation of tennis players. Raducanu shot into the spotlight with a surprise y run to the second week of Wimbledon - her Grand Slam debut tournament earlier this summer. And even before the tournament, it appears that Kate and husband Prince William were fans of the young Brit. In a tweet from July, the couple made their predictions of who would win Wimbledon and said: Unbiased prediction to win it: @andy_murray and @EmmaRaducanu #Wimbledon. news uk-news keen-runner-kate-middleton-reveals-"Kate and Wills go head to head on race trackByJenner Newton:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | comments In just over a weekaposs time, runners will be pounding the streets in the London Marathon - but the Duchess of Cambridge will not be among them.Sporty Kate is often seen at engagements trying her hand at all sorts of activities from running to tennis - and even abseiling. But it seems that taking part in the famous long-distance run in the English capital is one sporting event that she wonapost be taking part in, evenshe wanted to. Journalist Bryony Gordon, who has met Kate and completed the marathon, revealed she asked hershe would consider doing it. But Bryony told Runneraposs World : I can’t remember exactly what happened, but I was like, ‘Are you going to run the marathon ’And she was like, ‘Oh I can’t because security is a bit dficult.’ But I was like, ‘Sure, yeah, yeah, good excuse. If I can do it, anyone can.apos Despite not being able to take part, Kate did attend the  London Marathon when her mental health cause Heads Together was one of the main charities for that year - although she didnapost so any running.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up . Earlier this week, Kate got to show off her sporting prowess once again during an engagement with young air cadets in the Lake District.She was pictured mountain biking and abseiling - and tried her best at encouraging one reluctant youngster to take the plunge. Itelouwa Odipe, , from Lancaster, said he spoke to Kate as she waited to try abseiling. He said: She was about to abseil and I was next in line so she asked meI wanted to go before her. I was a bit scared so I said no. She saidI did she would meet me down there. The teenager spoke to her again after deciding not to brave the drop. She said it was really good and I should try it, he said. I think she was very kind. Even though she is a royal highness she still does things normal humans do. news uk-news meghan-harrys-uk--dficult-"Harry and Meghan: UK doesnt want them back says FarageByJenner Newton:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | comments The Royal Family will find Prince Harry and Meghan Markleapossto the UK dficult as there is a feeling they cannot be trusted, a royal biographer has claimed. There has been speculation that the couple could travel to the UK for Christmas and bring their children with them.Since moving to Calornia last year, Harry has only ed to the UK twice, while Meghan and two-year-old Archie have not been back so far.Meanwhile, Harry and Meghanaposs newborn daughter Lilibet has not been to the UK after being born in Calornia in June and is yet to meet her great-grandmother the Queen or her grandfather Prince Charles.Earlier this year, it was announced that Harry would be releasing a tell-all memoir about his le that would be released next year.And royal author Angela Levin, who has written a biography of Harry in the past, told True Royalty TVaposs The Royal Beat of a Christmas visit: I think it would cause a lot of people a lot of grief.The Queen would be delighted because she adores Harry - and also you love a child even though you disagree with everything they are doing - but I think for the other Royals, it is quite a stf time where everybody has a very explicit diary of changing five times a day and what they have to do at what time. I think it will be very, very dficultthey come over because the feeling is you can’t trust them, and they might use this for their next documentary or for his next book.” Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .Harry and Meghan are currently in the middle of their first public trip since quitting as senior royals - and have been out and about in New York. Yesterday, they visited the cityaposs highest building - the One World Trade Center, built on the site of the former World Trade Center, and its One World Observatory.They arrived hand-in-hand with Meghan dressed in an all-black outfit including what is thought to be an Emporio Armani coat, with matching black Aquazzura heels and her hair tied back off her face in a bun. Harry also wore a black suit.  They met with New York City mayor Bill de Blasio, his we Chirlane McCray and their son, Dante. They also met with New York governor Kathy Hochul. As they posed for pictures on the observation deck, Meghan was askedshe was enjoying her visit to New York and she replied: Itaposs wonderful to be back, thank you. Once the meeting was over, Harry and Meghan clutched each otheraposs hands as they walked to the   Memorial nearby.  Later they met with the US ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield.Writing on Twitter, the ambassador said they had an “important discussion” that included the pandemic, racial justice and raising awareness of mental health. The couple is believed to be staying at New Yorkaposs swanky £,-a-night Carlyle Hotel and were spotted sipping cocktails in its Bemelmans Bar.  The pair stayed in the bar for around three hours before leaving via the back door, MailOnline reports. Tomorrow, they will appear at the -hour star-studded global TV event Global Citizen Live in Central Park.At the event, they will continue their urgent work with world leaders in the pursuit of global vaccine equity to end the Covid- pandemic for everyone, everywhere. The event organisers call them two of the strongest voices on vaccine equity. The Royal Beat - available on True Royalty TV. news uk-news meghan-markle-gives-first-update-"Princess Diana’s brother genuinely looking forward to meeting LilibetByJenner Newton:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsMeghan Markle has given her first update on baby Lilibet, describing her little daughter as beautul. Meghan and husband Prince Harry in New York for a number of official engagements, their first public trip since quitting the UK for Calornia and stepping down as senior royals. Yesterday, they made a series of appearances around New York City and met with political figures, including the New York mayor Bill de Blasio and the US ambassador to the UN Linda Thomas-Greenfield. Harry and Meghan have made the trip to the city alone and are thought to have left three-month-old Lilibet and her big brother Archie at home in Calornia. Since Lilibetaposs birth in July, the couple have not released any images of the youngster and have hardly given any updates about her.But as they walked between engagements yesterday, one reporter from Inside Edition called out to the couple, asking: Meghan, howaposs Lilibet And Meghan simply replied: Sheaposs beautul. Another also asked: Howaposs Archie , to which Meghan gave a big thumbs up. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .The coupleaposs tour of New York continues today with Meghan appearing at a school in Harlem, where she read the young pupils her book The Bench. Yesterday marked Meghanaposs first public appearance since the birth of Lilibet when she and Harry visited the cityaposs highest building - the One World Trade Center, built on the site of the former World Trade Center, and its One World Observatory. As they posed for pictures on the observation deck, Meghan was askedshe was enjoying her visit to New York and she replied: Itaposs wonderful to be back, thank you. Once the meeting was over, Harry and Meghan clutched each otheraposs hands as they walked to the   Memorial nearby.Later they met with the US ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, who later wrote on Twitter that they had an “important discussion” that included the pandemic, racial justice and raising awareness of mental health. Tomorrow, the couple will appear at the -hour star-studded global TV event Global Citizen Live in Central Park. At the event, they will continue their urgent work with world leaders in the pursuit of global vaccine equity to end the Covid- pandemic for everyone, everywhere. The event organisers call them two of the strongest voices on vaccine equity. title: most common symptom tell difference
story: :root Most common symptom to tell the dference between Covid and a coldSymptoms of the Covid- virus are extremely similar to those of a regular cold, particularly for those who have been double jabbed.A crossover of symptoms makes it dficult to tell the dference between a cold and Covid- Image: Getty ImagesBySophie LawAdvance Content Writer:,  Sep | commentsIn a bid to help people distinguish between coronavirus and a common cold, scientists have revealed the ‘one’ symptom that sets the two apart. Experts have warned of a crossover of symptoms for the past  months, making it dficult to tell the dference between the two illnesses. Symptoms of the virus are extremely similar to those of a regular cold, particularly for those who have been double jabbed.Vaccinated people who contract the virus are likely to experience a runny nose, sore throat and sneezing, the Daily Record reported. But now, new research from the ZOE Covid Symptom study, developed by Kingaposs College London, has found that thereaposs one symptom that can help tell the dference.Data shows that loss of smellor loss of taste is still one of the most important predictors of testing positive for coronavirus rather than a regular cold.Researchers say you can check your sense of smell easily at home by snfing scented foods or products, or noticing whether familiar foods start to lose their flavour or taste strange. Millions of people have been logging their symptoms, tests and vaccines on the UK ZOE COVID Symptom Study app since it was launched. Thanks to health reports, scientists now know there are more than  symptoms of Covid-, including headache, runny nose, sneezing and sore throat. Common Covid symptoms in people fully vaccinated Data as of September : Runny nose Headache Sneezing Sore throat Loss of smellCommon COVID- symptomsyou’re unvaccinated Headache Runny Nose Sore Throat Fever Persistent cough Loss of smellcomes further down the list for unvaccinated people, but it’s still an important predictor of having COVID- rather than a regular cold. title: mum told too young breast
story: :root Mum told she was too young for breast cancer dies weeks after wedding dayMum-of-two Sinead Richards died on September  - just weeks after her wedding - after battling aggressive breast cancer that had spread through her bodySinead Richards, , died weeks after her wedding day Image: Richard Day   RD Photography   SWNSByJoe PagnelliDaniel SheridanRyan Fahey:,  Sep | commentsA mum-of-two told she was too young to have breast cancer has tragically died from the condition just weeks after her wedding day. Sinead Richards, , was the picture of happiness when she tied the knot with her partner of  years, Liam McDonagh, , on August . But she passed away on September , just over a year after tests revealed she had stage four breast cancer, which had spread through her body. She visited doctors in early  but they initially missed the tumour, believing the mum-of-two was too young to have breast cancer. Heartbroken Liam said of their wedding: “Everyone was smiling all day. She was very unwell but it really showed what she was like, she battled to get there and put on a brave face. It was mind over matter. She got herself there and that is all she wanted. It has had a huge impact on our lives. She was amazing, she was such a lovely person. Nobody she ever met had a bad word to say about her, everyone loved her. It is just so tragic. When we were in the hospital, people would give us a second glance as they couldnapost believe how young we were. She was only , we couldnapost believe it.” Mum-of-two Sinead, a pastoral mentor, found a lump on her breast in late  but put off visiting the doctors for two months as she did not think it would be cancer.  When she visited the doctors in early , nothing was initially discovered and Sinead was believed to be too young to suffer from breast cancer. But Liam urged Sinead toto the surgery and tests revealed she had advanced Stage Four breast cancer which had spread all over her body. Tragically, Sinead died on September , less than a month after their wedding, leaving behind Liam and their two daughters, Paige, seven, and Georgie, . Just one in four women survive for more than five years after they are diagnosed with the illness. Now Liam, a builder, has urged other women to get tested despite their age.  He added: If her story helps even one more person to get checked, this will have all been worthwhile. She was the most amazing person. I just want to show that this can happen to anyone and urge people to get checkedthey ever notice anything.A fundraiser has been launched on GoFundMe to support the family and help with costs of a funeral which will take place on October .A fun day at a local pub and a canal ride from Leeds to Liverpool have been organised in the fundraising drive – and more than £, has been raised so far. title: pensioner makes debut england age
story: :root Exclusive: Pensioner makes debut for England at age of  - and is cheered on by his dadJohn Shannons -year-old dad cheered him on from the sidelines when he took part in Englands first over-s side against Wales. John was joined by other pensioners who want to play the beautul gameJohn Shannons dad John Sr was there so see his son make his England debut Image: Julian Hamilton Daily MirrorByMartin Fricker:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsAt , John Shannon had his dream come true when he made his debut for England’s first over-s side in a - win against Wales – cheered on by his -year-old father. Having first proudly watched his lad from the touchline seven decades ago, John Senior was there again yesterday to see him make history. The Arsenal-supporting Second World War veteran said: “It was a fantastic game, they played some wonderful stuff. I do enjoy being on the side watching him play. “It makes me very proud to see my son playing for England.” West Ham fan John Junior, who was the oldest of the  England and Wales players in the inaugural NHS Challenge Trophy, said: “Everyone always asks after Dad, askinghe will be at the next game.  “He’s given me criticism over the years for other things in le but never criticises my footballing abilities. “I love playing matches. The standard is just as good as other age groups, albeit maybe a bit slower.” John Snr of Harrogate, North Yorks, who spent three years behind enemy lines in Belgium during the war, first watched his son play in school matches in the s, before the youngster switched to athletics. He began watching him again in his s, when John Jr, from Cambridge, was playing over-s football, and was named the FA’s Supporter of the Year in , at the age of . England’s player-manager Ken Pollock, , said: “The Shannons epitomise everything about what we stand for as a national team and as a sport. They’re father and son, aged  and , watching and playing. “There’s no finer testament to the benefits of our game than can be found in their match-day attendance.”  Although over-s have played walking football internationals, this was the first game with normal rules for England and Wales. The indoor game, at England’s St George’s Park headquarters in Burton, Staffs, was sanctioned by the FA. Unlike walking football it was played at speed with fierce tackles and crunching challenges – though ex-Premier League referee Dermot Gallagher made sure things did not get too heated between the fierce rivals. The game was arranged to promote exercise for the over-s. Ken added: “The pandemic has shown the importance of physical fitness. Statistically, exercise has been a preventative and curative agent for older people. To mark this, we called the cup The NHS Challenge Trophy, to reflect our gratitude for their work over the last  months.” The over-s side evolved from earlier over-s and over-s teams, which began competing in . Newcomers from across England took part in trials before being selected for the Three Lions.  Ken, from Pevensey Bay, Dorset, is the oldest player in his Sunday non-league side Grove Grovellers. And he loved lining up alongside players of his own age to represent his country. He told the Mirror: “The game isn’t much dferent in my s to what it was like in my younger years. The tackles still fly in, there is still the same competitiveness. “It’s still the same injuries, the hamstrings and the calf tears. It’s actually easier to play longer now-adays. Injuries can be diagnosed earlier and treatment is better.” Other players in yesterday’s game included Everton fan Mike Unwin, , a retired primary school head from West Kirby, Merseyside. Holly Murdoch, general manager at St George’s Park, said: “We hope this inspires the older generation to dust off their boots and get playing again.” England won the game -. John Snr, who lives in Harrogate, North Yorks, spent three years behind enemy lines in Belgium during World War II.  His son made his England debut aged , something John Snr described as his “proudest moment” as a parent. John Snr was crowned the FA’s ‘Supporter of the Year’ in , when aged , for his devotion to football. He first started watching his son play matches for his school in the s, before the youngster switched to athletics. John Snr only began watching him again when he was in his s, by which time John Jnr was playing over-s football. The Arsenal fan told the Mirror after yesterday’s match: “It was a fantastic game, they played some wonderful stuff.  “I do enjoy being on the side watching him play. It makes me very proud to see my son playing for England.” West Ham-supporting John Jnr, from Cambridge, added: “Everyone always asks after dad, askinghe will be at the next game. “He’s given me criticism over the years for other things in le but never criticises my footballing abilities. “I love playing matches. The standard is just as good as other age groups, albeit maybe a bit slower.” Comment MORE ON Premier LeagueThe FAWorld War EducationPeople" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: perfectly preserved art deco house
story: :root Inside treasure trove house frozen in time since s as it goes on sale for £.mThe Grade II listed home in south London is on the market for £.m and comes with a treasure trove for period furniture loversThe colourful abode is one of just a handful of homes designed by s design duo Kemp  Taske Image: HamptonsByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA perfectly preserved Art Deco house that hasn’t changed since the s has come on the market for the first time since . The property on Dorchester Drive, Herne Hill in south London, has an asking price of £.m and comes with original aposs radiators, original Crittall windows and an original kitchen. The home is just one of handful designed by the design duo Kemp  Tasker, who are perhaps best known for their cinemas. Boasting three receptions rooms, two toilets and five bedrooms, the house also has a large garden, iron staircase, “sunspan” curved windows in the living room, roof terrace, original hardwood flooring, and aposs tiled bathroom.The sellers Hamptons have suggested that the two reception rooms could be knocked into one to create a ft “ballroom”.In  a Kemp  Tasker house design won the Daily Mailaposs Ideal House Competition and was erected temporarily at Olympia in the Village of Tomorrow at Ideal Home Show the following year. The builders, Bromley-based Messrs Morrell Bros. Builders advertised that the home could be built to order anywhere but only three known examples exist - in Dublin, Hayes in Kent and this one on the market. A spokesperson for Hamptons said: Owned by the same family since , this house now provides the opportunity for a buyer to breathe new le into a well-loved family home to create something really special in terms of style and space. It has wonderful features such as curved doors, original hardwood flooring , original Crittall windows, the fabulous apossunspanapos curved window in the lounge, grand iron staircase and original tiled bathroom. There is a wraparound garden and off-street parking on both sides. The original sales brochure described the ground floor as having the option of combining the two reception rooms with the hall to create a forty ft ballroom. Its beautul wooden floor, believed to be maple, also extends into the study which has full- window views over the garden. The roof is a perfect spot to enjoy the sun and the views over London. There is an additional room on the roof, not shown on the floor plan, housing the water tank and providing useful extra storage space. news uk-news petrol-stations-closed-and-fuel-"BP announce petrol station forecourt closures in statementByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Sep | comments A national fuel shortage is causing petrol stations across the country to close, risking widespread disruption. The UK has been plagued by a number of shortages in recent weeks, brought on by a shortage of HGV drivers.BPaposs head of UK retail Hanna Hofer has said it is important the government understands the urgency of the situation, which she described as bad, very bad, ITV News reports.She added that BP had two-thirds of normal forecourt stock levels required for smooth operations and the level is declining rapidly. Here we take a look at which oil companies have faced petrol station closures, and the reason for the fuel shortage. Which petrol stations have closed   BP and Tesco have closed some petrol stations because of petrol and diesel supply issues, brought on by the lack of HGV drivers. There are around , BPO branded filling stations around the country, of which  are operated by BP themselves, and the oil giant has said a handful of these have been forced to close. The oil giant, which is the largest operator of petrol stations in the UK, has not said which specic ones have closed.  The Mirror reached out to BP, but the company could not confirm which specic petrol stations were closed due to the fast-changing situation. BP said in a statement: “We are experiencing some fuel supply issues at some of our retail sites in the UK and unfortunately have therefore seen a handful of sites temporarily close due to a lack of both unleaded and diesel grades. These have been caused by some delays in the supply chain which has been impacted by the industry-wide driver shortages across the UK and there are many actions being taken to address the issue. We continue to work with our haulier supplier to minimise any future disruption and to ensure efficient and effective deliveries to serve our customers.  They are currently working to address the problem, and prioritising deliveries to motorway service areas, major trunk roads and sites with the largest demands. The company said: We continue to work with our haulier supplier to minimise disruption and to ensure efficient and effective deliveries. Esso, which owns  Tesco Alliance sites, has reported similar issues with a small number of them. A spokesperson said: We are working closely with all parties in our distribution network to optimise supplies and minimise any inconvenience to customers. “We apologise to our customers for any inconvenience.” Currently these are the only two suppliers reporting shortages. Supermarket Morrisons has said itaposs not seeing similar issues with any of its  petrol stations, according to the BBC. Similarly, Co-Op, which operates  petrol stations, has a full complement of fuel delivery drivers. Tesco says it has a good availability of fuel, and the BBC report that both Sainsburyaposs and Asda have had no issues in fuel supplies. Why is there a fuel shortage   Is panic-buying understandable - or selfish  Let us know in the comments below Similarly to the food shortage which is causing empty supermarket shelves, the reason for the fuel shortage is to do disruption to the supply chain. This is due to a post-Brexit shortage in the number of HGV drivers. Since the UK left the European Union, many non-UK nationals who drive trucks have opted to work solely within EU countries. This has left logistics firms struggling to find workers. According to The Road Haulage Association , Britain needs as many as , more drivers to keep shops stocked and supplies moving.The coronavirus situation has made everything worse, with the closure of test centres worsening the shortage of drivers.The Department for Transport has recently changed the rules for tests to speed up the process of qualication.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BPExxon Mobil CorporationEuropean Union" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: proof kate middleton sportiest royal
story: :root Proof Kate Middleton is sportiest royal ever - and which games she thrashes William atAfter Kate Middleton has a go at abseiling and mountain biking during an action-packed visit to the Lake District, we look back at her seriously sporty historyThe daring duchess is up for any challenge Image: Daily Mirror Andy StenningByAlex BellottiNews Features Writer:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsWeaposve seen the Queen at the races and Prince William watching his beloved Aston Villa, but is there any royal more sporty than the Duchess of Cambridge  Over the years, Kate has tried her hand at almost as many sports as there are at the Olympics, proving sheaposs capable at everything from sailing to cricket and even table tennis.This week, the -year-old decided it was time to have a go at abseiling and mountain biking during an action-packed visit to the Lake District.Kate was photographed taking the plunge at Cathedral Quarry in Little Langdale, Cumbria, after going biking with a group of Air Cadets.The sporty streak appears to stretch way back to her teenage years, with school pal Gemma Williamson telling the Daily Mail that “every boy in school fancied her rotten after she impressed them with her talent at hockey and cross-country running.Here, we take a look at the duchessapos finest sporting moments - and how the competitive royal stacks up against her husband Wills. Sailing Kate has a deep love of sailing and showed off her skills in  at the King’s Cup regatta off the Isle of Wight - although she was beaten to the finish line by William. Itaposs no surprise that sheaposs also struck up a friendship with Olympics sailing hero Sir Ben Ainslie, whoaposs even taken her out on the water. Get the biggest news delivered to your inbox.for the Mirroraposs free newslettersThis summer, the Cambridges are said to have made the most of the fleeting sunshine by taking a boat around the Norfolk coast.A local source told Vanity Fairaposs Katie Nicholl that they are very much a family of sailors now after getting the kids up to speed while staying at their holiday home Anmer Hall in early August.“Kate has always been a competent sailor and William’s pretty good too, said the source. Volleyball Donning a pair of five-inch wedges, perhaps Kate was looking for a height advantage when she tried her hand at volleyball. In her first solo engagement since the birth of Prince George, the royal joined young athletes and their parents in education workshops for her charity SportsAid in  - but wasnapost quite dressed for the part in her skinny jeans. The Russell and Bromley heels didnapost stop her at the volleyball net but she did tell one young fencer: Iaposd like to give it a go but Iaposve brought the wrong shoes. She chatted to aspiring athletes and watched them play badminton, volleyball, fencing and wheelchair basketball before posing for a photo with the group. Kate was joined at Londonaposs Olympic Park Copper Box by rower Katherine Grainger and wheelchair basketball player Ade Adepitan as they tutored the next generation of Britainaposs athletes. Hockey Hockey is one of Kateaposs first sporting loves. Sheaposs very good too, having captained her team as a schoolgirl at Marlborough College. Back in , the duchess swapped her skirt suit and heels for a tracksuit top and trainers to join Great Britain’s women’s Olympic hockey team.  And she even grabbed a hockey stick and joined in the practice session herself during her visit to the London  Olympic Park. The dressed-down royal ditched her trademark LK Bennett heels for comfortable trainers as she ran around the pitch at the Riverside Arena in bright coloured skinny jeans .The Duchess’s visit boosted the team, and some took to Twitter to share their excitement.England and GB hockey player Kate Walsh wrote: “A real pleasure and an honour to meet and play hockey with HRH the Duchess of Cambridge this morning!  “Think our team have got Royal approval!” Hannah Macleod praised Kate’s sporting skills, adding: “A pleasure and an honour to meet HRH the Duchess of Cambridge this morning at the Olympic Park. “Sheaposs quite handy at hockey too!” Table tennis As a spectator, Kate can often be spotted in the royal box at Wimbledon watching stars like Andy Murray. A patron of the Lawn Tennis Association, sheaposs also partial to the slightly less sophisticated game of ping pong too.  After sister Pippa boasted about her familyaposs skills back in , the duchess displayed the ‘Middleton competitiveness’ when she took on William during their Scotland visit. Onlookers agreed mum-to-be Kate was the better player as the royal couple had a knockabout at the Donald Dewar leisure centre in the Drumchapel area of the city. The pair were joined in a doubles match by teenagers Yaser Razouk and Stephen Grimes.  Both boys, members of the Drumchapel Table Tennis Club, agreed that Kate won in her match against William. Yaser said he thought they would make a really good doubles team. He said: We knew before they came that we were going to give them the bats, but I never thought weaposd end up playing with them. When they were playing each other at singles William was convinced he was winning but I think it was Kate who ended up the winner. Her knack for table tennis appears to extend into the full court game too.Speaking to the Daily Mail, Australian former world number one Rod Laver said: I’d met William and Kate a few times, and in the Royal Box you get a chance to chat with them a little bit.They play tennis against each other. William told me he couldn’t beat her. Rowing The sight of Kate at the helm of a Dragon Boat on the River Thames is one of the defining images of her love story with Prince William. The royal made her now infamous appearance in the boat in  following a brief split from William as the The Sisterhood rowing team prepared for a cross-Channel race in the traditional Chinese vessel against all-boys crew the Brotherhood. The challenge drew throngs of attention from round the world and, though Kate eventually pulled out over security fears, her team went on to complete the gruelling race. The images were so renowned they even made their way into Hollywood’s William and Kate film, which came out shortly before the couple wed. High jump Like that one annoyingly brilliant friend we all know, Kate has proved herself to be a dab hand at nearly every sport over the ears. Sheaposs had a go at cricket, football tennis and even given archery hurdles a go. Perhaps one of the lesser known facts about the accomplished sportwoman, though, is that she still holds a school record in one field. A talented high jumper, Kate set the still-standing record of . metres when she was a pupil at St Andrewaposs School in Pangbourne, Berkshire, which she attended from  to . Clearly, nothingaposs too much of a leap for the daring duchess.Got a story  Get in touch by emailing alex.bellotti@reachplcComment MORE ON Kate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeRoyal FamilyPrince WilliamWilliam and Kate" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news queens-grandchild-louise-windsor-make-"Lady Louise Windsor shares memories of Prince PhilipByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThe Queenaposs aposfavourite grandchildapos will decide whether or not she wants to take the title of princess in a matter of weeks. Lady Louise Alice Elizabeth Mountbatten-Windsor, , is the daughter of Prince Edward and Sophie, the Countess of Wessex.This week she stepped into the spotlight to commemorate her grandfather Prince Philip in a BBC documentary. Prince Philip: The Royal Family Remembers aired on BBC One on September , and featured interviews from all of the Queen and The Duke of Edinburghaposs children and adult grandchildren.  Among those who paid tribute was Lady Louise, who recalled her close bond with Prince Philip and their shared love for carriage driving. She is the th in line to the throne and is the grandchild of the Queen, , and her late husband Philip. When her parents Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones got married in , Buckingham Palace announced their children would not be styled as prince or princess. Instead Louise and her brother James, Viscount Severn, are titled as children of an earl. The decision was said to be part of Edward and Sophieaposs hopes for their children to have as normal a childhood as possible.  Thereports that the final decision on whether to take the title of princess will be left up to Louise when she turns . She will choose whether or not to style herself Her Royal Highness Princess Louise after her birthday with her parents, the Earl and Countess of Wessex, said to be leaving the decision up to their daughter. If she decides to take the new title, she will be styled as Her Royal Highness Princess Louise. The Queenaposs other grandchildren have a mixture of titles with Louiseaposs cousins Princess Beatrice and Eugenie also styling themselves as HRH. Princess Anneaposs children Zara Tindall and Peter Phillips have never held HRH status.  Due to the the  Letters Patent HRH titles could only be passed onto the children of the sovereign, the children of the sovereign’s sons, and the eldest living son of the eldest son of the Prince of Wales. This was amended in  to include all the children of the eldest son of the Prince of Wales. As a result all of the Duke of Cambridgeaposs children have HRH status. Royal expert, Phil Dampier, said that as she comes of age Louise could prove to be the monarchyaposs apossecret weapon.apos He said: Because she’s the granddaughter of the Queen, Lady Louise can call herself a princess when she becomes ... and there’s a strong argument for her doing it.  “She seems to be very mature for her age, and she’s shaping up to be precisely the kind of person the Queen can rely on in the future. “Could there be a role for her in a slimmed-down monarchy  The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh had , patronages between them. You have to ask yourself who is going to continue their legacy, what with Harry and Meghan and Prince Andrew off the scene  There’s a huge workload there.”Meanwhile, there have been several reports that Lady Louise is the Queenaposs favourite grandchild due to their special bond.A royal source previously told The Sun: The Queen loves the fact that Louise and James relish their time at Balmoral, and she has become particularly close to Louise, who seems to have become her favourite grandchild, closely followed by James. The source added: “Louise also endeared herself to everyone by looking after William and Kate’s children when they were up here. “Louise loves drawing and sketching and was very patiently trying to get Charlotte to do pictures of rabbits and deer. Because of her obvious artistic skill, the Queen allowed Louise to look through some of the collection of Queen Victoria’s Highlands sketches which are kept at Balmoral but are rarely dug out these days.” While the spotlight mainly focuses on Princes William and Harry, the Queen has eight grandchildren, and she is said to be close with them all. title: raf musicians house loses 20000
story: :root RAF musicians house loses £, in value because of overgrown garden next doorFred Sweenie, who played for the Queen, says that his mental health is suffering as a result of the state of his next door neighbours gardenMusician Fred Sweenie, who has performed in Royal shows, says he has become very ill from stress Image: MEN MEDIAByGeorge BunnShiler Mahmoudi:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA retired RAF musician has been told his house has lost £, in value because of a neighbouraposs overgrown garden. Musician Fred Sweenie, who has previously played for the Queen, is struggling with his mental health as a result of the issue.The Royal musician from Burntwood once had his property valued by an agent, but was told that the next door house would knock off at least £, from the value of his home.The semi-detached house next door is so overgrown that sunlight is blocked out and the giant trees mean his family cannot enjoy their garden, Staffordshire Live reports.He says that he has spotted rats running around his garden, and that he will never be able to sell his house as potential buyers will be put off by the state of the property next door.  These issues have left him feeling that his country is letting me down, and he is frustrated that for twelve years, nothing has been done to help his situation. Mr Sweenie played in the RAF Central band for  years and has performed at events including garden parties for the Queen and the Cenotaph in London. He has also toured with former Yes keyboardist, Rick Wakeman. The musician and his we Janet, , and son Guy, , have been complaining about the property to Lichfield council for over a decade, and state that no one has occupied the property for  years.  He said: Every time we try to do something it gets blocked. We donapost know why. We first moved into the property in Rugeley Road in . At the time, next door was well kept and well maintained. This really started to go wrong around  years ago. Our first complaint was around  years ago. It came about after we heard a humming noise coming from next door. We enquired and it turned out the wiring was archaic which led us to be worried about a possible fire hazard. Mr Sweenie added: By , the garden next door was having a serious impact on our health and wellbeing.  Rats had started to appear in our garden and we could see the holes where they were coming in. We reported it to environmental health. No response there. So we went to Mr Fabricantwho was fantastic. He wrote numerous times to the council requesting a full investigation into the property. When they did undergo a full investigation, they said that the property was occupied and that, apart from one shed that was full of food waste that had to be knocked down, there was no need to do anything . It made me very ill and we dropped the inquiries in . I was getting nightmares. That was the worst time I think. The house combined with the rats and the fact that we get no light in our garden because of the towering trees really made me ill. All of these issues have meant thathe ever chooses to sell the property, it will be listed for £, less than it is actually worth because of the nightmare garden next door. Head of corporate services at Lichfield District Council Tracey Tudor said: When investigating this type of neighbourhood complaint we need to establish that the condition of land or buildings is harmful to the area, which is not straightforward.  Having visited the garden on Rugeley Road a number of times, we have found that, although is overgrown, it has a clear path from either end, has plants rather than weeds, and is not covered in litter or dumped items. The owner has told us that he likes his plants and trees to attract wildle. While the garden may not be to everyone’s taste, we do not believe it breaches any planning laws that govern complaints of this nature, and when comparing it to similar cases. While some of the neighbours may not like the garden, others do as it does as it attracts birds. Although there is a dference of opinion about how back gardens should be presented, there are insufficient grounds for us to serve a notice. According to Lichfield council, the next door neighbour has agreed to cut back on some vegetation this month as a compromise. title: rats invading homes through toilets
story: :root Rats invading homes through toilets as one shocked woman finds pest in bathroomAndrew Dellbridge, head of Ace Pest Control, has seen rats as big as cats in Norwich with rodents becoming bigger and braver, forcing one couple in the city to leave their homeHuge rats are climbing up toilets in Norwich, leaving residents with a nasty shockImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByMatthew DreschReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsRats are invading homes through toilets, with one woman left in shock after spotting a rodent below her when she was using the bathroom. Andrew Dellbridge, head of Ace Pest Control, said rats in Norwich are getting aposbigger and braverapos, forcing one couple in the city to leave their home. He said another customer was left speechless when she used her bathroom, heard a noise and then saw a rat in the toilet bowl below her. Mr Dellbridge said the terrying episode is becoming increasingly common and he has spotted rats aposas big as catsapos in the city. He told the Norwich Evening News: I was called out to one job in Norwich and the customer could barely speak, she was in so much shock. Sheaposd been using the bathroom and heard a noise. She looked down and it was in the toilet bowl. And this is happening more and more frequently. They used to work around us but now theyaposre gaining access they wouldnapost have attempted before. Mr Dellbridge added that the issue is becoming worse due to overflowing bins and wild verges being filled with rubbish. The pest control boss has been working flat-out through the summer, despite the winter usually being his busiest time of the year. He said cats are no longer a solution to a vermin problem as aposa sensible cat doesnapost like a big ratapos. It comes after huge rats ran riot in lockdown Britain - with easy access to food meaning the vermin grew in size and number.  Footage showed a pair of them - the size of a small cat - stealing food from hungry birds. The plump animals climbed up the frame before gorging themselves on the food. The large rodents were scampering around in broad daylight in full view of a family in Accrington, Lancs. Experts said the easy access to food - with many businesses closed during the pandemic - caused the UKaposs rat population to skyrocket. The number of rats increased from  million to  million during , according to pest control company pest.  The big freeze, lockdowns and food stockpiling created the ideal environment for rats and mice to enjoy a little quiet time in vacant buildings. A rataposs bite is in fact six times stronger, relative to their size, than a great white shark, pest expert Jenny Rathbone said. Pest controllers have seen evidence of cunning rats moving a crisp packet and placing it over a glue trap, to enable them to travel across it without being caught. title: sabina nessa flatmate texting teacher
story: :root Sabina Nessas flatmate sent final texts to teacher just moments after she vanishedPrimary school teacher Sabina, , from Kidbrooke, Greenwich in London, was killed as she walked across Cator Park on the way to meet a friend just minutes from her flatSabina, , from Kidbrooke, Greenwich in London, was killed as she walked across Cator Park Image: politan Police AFP via GettByAbigail OLearyReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep Sabina Nessaaposs flatmate said she was texting the teacher shortly before she was killed minutes from home. Primary school teacher Sabina, , from Kidbrooke, Greenwich in London, was killed as she walked across Cator Park. Her body was found  hours later close on Saturday evening close to the OneSpace community centre. The year one primary school teacher had been minutes away from meeting a friend at a pub when she was killed at around :pm. Her flatmate, who did not want to be named, had seen her earlier that day, saying: “I never thought something like this could happen to her.  She told“I had been texting her and it’s not like her to not reply to my messages. I don’t feel safe living here now.” The politan Police said a man was arrested in Lewisham, south east London. The force also released CCTV images of a man they wish to speak to and a vehicle they are searching for. This is the second arrest the politan Police has made in connection with the attack. On Saturday, detectives arrested a man in his s on suspicion of murder, who was then released under further investigation. The images of the man, taken from CCTV, shows him walking in Pegler Square on the evening Sabina was attacked. Police have also released an image of a silver vehicle they believe the man has access to, which was also captured in the Pegler Square area. They are urging anyone who recognises the man and vehicle to make contact immediately. Detective Chief Inspector Neil John, from the Met’s Specialist Crime Command, said: “Our team have been working tirelessly to find the person responsible for Sabina’s murder and this has included an extensive trawl of CCTV, work which remains ongoing. Ms Nessaaposs cousin Zubel Ahmed said previously her parents are inconsolable after their loss.  In an interview with the BBC, he said: We are all truly devastated. Her parents are absolutely shocked, theyaposre inconsolable still and understandably so, to hear of their daughter being taken away from them by some cowardly man is just horric. She honestly was the most caring person, kindest, sweetest girl you could meet. Sabinaaposs heart was as good as gold, she never had a bad word to say about anyone. Her sister is going to miss her so much. A vigil has been planned in Sabinaaposs memory by Reclaim These Streets, an organisation working to raise awareness of womenaposs safety across the country. The vigil will take place on Friday evening at Pegler Square in Kidbrooke at pmMost ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON politan Police ServiceCrimeMurderPoliceSabina Nessa" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: sabina nessa how men can
story: :root Sabina Nessa: How men can help women feel safer while walking alone at nightThe murder of Sabina Nessa, six months after the death of Sarah Everard, has once again thrown the topic of womens safety walking the streets of UK towns to the forefront of conversation Image: REUTERSByAndrea Oldereide:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep  In the course of less than a month, two high-profile cases of women being murdered have sparked debates on how society can better womenaposs safety – the recent murder of American YouTuber Gabby Petito and of British school teacher Sabina Nessa. Femicide, the killing of a girl or woman, is a topic that has already been highlighted earlier this year, when Sarah Everard, a -year-old marketing executive, was killed in South London, on her walk back home. These victims tragically add to a horrying statistic that has been recently reported: six women are killed every hour by men around the world, according to UN data. Additionally, a woman is killed by a man every three days in the UK. According to Karen Ingala Smith, co-founder of the Femicide Census, men’s violence against women is a leading cause of the premature death for women globally but research in the UK and Europe is limited and unconnected. Dr Nilufar Ahmed who works as a Behavioural Psychologist at the University of Bristol helped us identy things men can do to help women feel safer and ways to stop violence towards women. How men can help feel women feel safer while walking alone  Being taught consent from a young age Men should learn to accept a womanaposs lack of interest in them. Violence inflicted on women is often entangled with sexual assaults, and therefore should be educated on consent. According to the United Nations Women , freely given and enthusiastic consent should be mandatory, “every time”. UN Women added that phrases like “she was asking for it” or “boys will be boys” attempt to blur the lines around sexual consent, placing blame on victims, and “excusing perpetrators from the crimes they have committed”.  Dr Nilufar Ahmed explained to the Mirror that changing our social attitudes was something that needed to happen across society and from an early age. She said: Understanding consent from an early age. ‘No means no’ is often framed in terms of sexual consent and rape, but it has a much bigger application –someone is rejecting your attention, friendship, or company in any setting, respect this. Schools can play a role in this by teaching young children about respecting boundaries. Being taught gender equality in schools The World Health Organisationpublished a pamphlet revealing that gender inequalities increase the risk of violence by men against women and inhibit the ability of those affected to seek protection. Experts have found that exposing children to non-stereotypical characters found in books and movies, as well as iding housework equally at home, can help children understand the notion that all genders are equal. Stop victim blaming Victim blaming is a way for someone to justy their motivation behind their own crime, while literally blaming their victim for their own action. Too often the behaviour and personalities of the women is scrutinised and judged first before the actions of the man who attacked them. Dr Nilufar Ahmed told The Mirror. She added: As though it is inevitable that a lone woman walking in the dark is automatically at risk of being attacked.  This victim blaming exonerates men from responsibility and blame by focusing on the woman. Allied with this, often when men commit heinous crimes, their crimes are qualied with added information about their lives as ‘good fathers’ or ‘high achieving students’, whilst the women are described only in terms of the way they were dressed and their actions that night. Becoming a better ally to women Doing something as simple as listening to women and their experiences goes a long way. Men should be able to acknowledge their privilege, as well as taking women’s concerns as a serious issue. Furthermore, men should not shy away from calling out blatant sexism and misogynistic behaviour when they witness it. Being supportive and contributing to the safety of women starts by becoming an ally. Destigmatise men’s mental health As the WHO found that potential perpetrators may be at an increased risk of committing femicidethey are unemployed, own a firearm, have made previous threats to kill with a weapon, or have committed sexual violence, men’s mental health needs to be addressed. Saying things like “man up” or “boys don’t cry” nourishes a culture of toxic masculinity which both prevents men from expressing their feelings, but also lead to dangerous behaviour such as resulting in violence instead of communication. According to Dr Nilufar Ahmed, there is not one reason that pushes men to harm and kill women, but it can include psychological reasons such as feeling rejected, feeling incapable of attracting a partner, being angry, feeling emasculated, a need to assert control, feeling entitled. These do not necessarily have to be about women – a man may experience repeated rejection from jobs, be angry at their landlord, etc, She said. She continued: Unaddressed, this can boil over and be projected onto a target that men are stronger than – women. Most men experiencing these will not go on to harm women butthese feelings are overwhelming go unresolved they can be damaging to the inidual and others around them, and could in extreme circumstances lead to aggression and even murder. If men are struggling with any of these issues accessing mental health support can help to work through them. Facilitate women’s access to protection and safety against domestic violence The WHO has revealed that there is an increased risk of perpetuating femicidethe aggressor has a history of intimate partner or family violence. A men with a history of domestic violence thereby is more likely to murder his partner. Domestic violence is reportedly not taken seriously in UK courts, as criminologist Jane Monkton-Smith toldthat her examination of  domestic abuse killings shows how sentences for manslaughter convictions were often mitigated by “ridiculous claims, like how much the perpetrator said they loved the victim”. Immediate things men can do to help according to a psychologist Dr Nilufar Ahmed said: Immediate things men can do are to be mindful to keep a safe distance from women when out walking or running. If you see a situation where a woman looks uncomfortable don’t be afraid to intervene either yourself or by making someone  aware .As a society we must all take responsibility for collective behaviours and actions. This means calling out comments and behaviour that are disrespectful to women whenever we encounter them. news uk-news sabina-nessa-latest-new-cctv-"Sabina Nessa: CCTV footage released of man Met police are seekingByTalia ShadwellReporter:,  Sep  Detectives investigating the murder of schoolteacher Sabina Nessa have released CCTV video footage of a man urgently being sought by police.Scotland Yard footage and moving CCTV still captures of the man which show him walking in Pegler Square in Kidbrooke, south-east London, on the evening the -year-old was attacked. A -second clip shows a balding man wearing a black hooded coat and grey jeans looking over his shoulder and pulling at his hood as he walks down a path. The Met spokesperson told the Mirror earlier today the force was not speculating about the appearance of the manaposs hands or reports of how Sabina may have been killed. Earlier today reports claim police sources believe she was pounced upon and attacked with a hammer just moments after leaving her flat on what should have been a five-minute walk across a park to her pub date.  Detectives have also released an image, captured in the Pegler Square area of Kidbrooke, of a silver car they believe the man has access to. The Met has appealed for anyone who recognised either to contact the force immediately. Detective chief inspector Neil John, from the Metaposs Specialist Crime Command, said an extensive trawl of CCTV in the area continued and said information on the manaposs identity and whereabouts could be vital to the investigation. Sabina was walking to meet a date at The Depot bar in Pegler Square near her home at around .pm last Friday when she was attacked.  A member of the public found her body under a pile of leaves close to the OneSpace community centre in Cator Park, in the borough of Greenwich, on Saturday at around .pm. The politan Police said a -year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of Sabinaaposs murder. The suspect was arrested at an address in Lewisham on Thursday and is being questioned in custody. It is the second arrest Scotland Yard has made in connection with the attack. On Saturday, detectives arrested a man in his s on suspicion of murder before he was released under further investigation.  Ms Nessaaposs cousin Zubel Ahmed remembered her as a beautul soul who loved teaching, telling the BBC that she was the most caring person - kindest, sweetest girl you could meet. Lisa Williams, the head of Rushey Green Primary School where Ms Nessa taught, said staff and pupils are taking our time to reflect and process the devastating news of her death and will be remembering the teacher privately. In a statement, Mrs Williams said: We have shared the details about the vigil with our school community and some people may be attending on a personal level to privately pay their respects.  As a school we are taking our time to reflect and process the devastating news we received this week, and will be commemorating Sabina in our own way. The vigil is being held on Friday evening at pm at Pegler Square, and people who cannot attend are being encouraged to hold a candle at their doorstep at the same time. Reclaim These Streets, a campaign group involved in supporting the Kidbrooke communityaposs vigil for Sabina, said it is angry and heartbroken about her murder. Tower Hamlets Councillor Rabina Khan told BBC Radio aposs Today programme said she was attending the vigil this evening and hoped high profile people would also attend. I too, just like my daughters, I have a -year-old, I have a -year-old, we spoke up for Sarah Everard, she said. When we saw high profile people who attended , I was really pleased and proud that the Duchess of Cambridge attended the vigil... news uk-news sabina-nessas-family-shocked-brutal-"-year-old Margaret Keenan gets her Covid- booster vaccineByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep The family of primary school teacher Sabina Nessa have said they are shocked by her brutal murder and are still struggling to understand how she did not make it home safely. Ms Nessa, , was taking a five-minute walk to meet a friend at The Depot bar in Pegler Square near her home in Kidbrooke, south-east London, on September  at around .pm when she was attacked. A member of the public found her body close to the OneSpace community centre in Cator Park on Saturday at around .pm. A -year-old man arrested in connection with the murder has been released under investigation, the politan Police said today.  The man was arrested on Thursday at an address in Lewisham, south-east London, and detectives are continuing to appeal for information about another man captured on CCTV in Pegler Square on the evening Ms Nessa was attacked. In a statement released to the PA news agency ahead of a rally at the East London Mosque, her sister Jebina Yasmin Islam said: We as a family are shocked of the murder of our sister, daughter and aunty to my girls. There are no words to describe how we are feeling as a family at the moment. We did not expect that something likewould ever happen to us. I urge everyone to walk on busy streets when walking home from work, school or a friendaposs homes. Please keep safe.  I ask you to pray for our sister and make duafor her. May Allahgrant her paradise. Halima Begum, chief executive of the Runnymede Trust race equality think tank, told PA: Speaking as a woman and a Londoner from the cityaposs Bangladeshi community, Iaposm heartbroken. Sabina is related to members of my extended family and everything I know about her speaks of a beautul, intelligent young woman who had so much le to live, and so, so much to offer in terms of making a positive dference to the peopleaposs lives she touched, not least her familyaposs and the young children she taught at school. Tragically, gender-based violence does not occur in isolation. I do not know how many more women will suffer before our streets are safe. What I do know is that Sabinaaposs death fills all of us with grief. Londoners, regardless of their gender, are hopeful that Sabinaaposs murderer will be found and brought to justice swtly.  Community leaders and Asian women, some of whom said they were too wary to attend a vigil for Ms Nessa on Friday night in south-east London but still wanted to show their solidarity in a location they feel safe, are among those who are gathering at the mosque. Fridayaposs events in memory of Ms Nessa come a week after she died and as the public spotlight is thrown on womenaposs safety and gender-based violence. Her death comes after the public outrage and protests over the abduction and murder of -year-old marketing executive Sarah Everard as she walked home alone in south London in March. Sufia Alam, of the East London Mosque and the Maryam Centre, said: This brutal murder of one of our shining stars is genuinely saddening and deeply shocking. I have three daughters, and I canapost even begin to express what I am feeling right now. Sarah Everard was one of our daughters, and so was Sabina Nessa - their lives were tragically cut short - at the hands of violence and brutality. We have much work to do against the violence faced by women in our society. We will not stop campaigning until our mothers, sisters and daughters are safe anywhere and everywhere. She said this state of affairs is not just about women and girls being vulnerable, this is about men and boys and educating them early on about respecting and honouring women and girls, and treating them with the dignity they deserve. Ms Alam, who is set to be at the east London rally where many women are due to attend, added: When a Muslim woman is murdered, this dampens the aspirations of other Muslim women and girls in education and employment - and this will be particularly hard for us to deal with and manage.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON House of CommonsMurderCrimePoliticsHate crimeSabina Nessa" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
